column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80143,2018,Economics for Econometricians,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. AP Markiewicz', 'dr. D Sisak', 'prof.dr. OR Marie']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86513,2018,Economics for Governance,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The course provides a non-mathematical introduction to how different groupings of economists view an economy and economic phenomena.  That is to say, the approach adopted is a comparative one.  Two broad schools of economic thought are identified: the Neo-classical school and Keynesian/Institutionalist schools.  The groupings are founded on perceived shared views on approach and method, basic building blocks of economic analysis, explanations of economic phenomena, and policy conclusions.  Particular attention is paid to certain of the building blocks since these provide important foundations for many of the ensuing majors.  Some of the most important of
these building blocks are the operation of commodity and factor markets, the concept of elasticity, the circular flow of income, and aggregate supply and demand.

The course comprises two interrelated parts.  The first part is devoted to the study of so-called microeconomic phenomena, including the operation of individual commodity and factor markets.  The second part is concerned with macroeconomic phenomena, including economic growth and development, inflation and the balance of payments.

The basic philosophy underlying the teaching of the course is that there is no such thing as a single, agreed, homogenous body of economic thought that one can label as “economics”, nor can economics be treated as a science in the same way as one or another of the disciplines in the physical sciences.  Accordingly, students are encouraged to consider the theories they are learning about in the course critically, and with the hindsight of their own experiences.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: By the end of the course students should possess;
1. A critical, non-technical (i.e., non-mathematical) understanding of contemporary economic thought.

2. An appreciation of fundamental differences between major schools of economic thought in economics, and the significance these differences have for their respective perspectives regarding action and policy.
3. A de-mystified view of key economic concepts and a non-jargonised view of crucial issues.
4. The ability to read, digest and make use of economics-related research reports and other materials in decision making.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After completing the course, students should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective on cultural heritage. They will be aware of the relevance of economic concepts and management issues related to cultural heritage and sites as well as of the main policy dilemmas arising in this field.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83175,2018,Economics of Cultural Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Mignosa'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course will introduce the main concepts related to tourism in general: its development, its economic impact, the main definitions and concepts (tourist, visitor, excursionist, carrying capacity of a destination), and the trends characterizing the sector and modifying it. The course will then focus on cultural tourism: a specific branch of tourism that is expanding though it is still difficult to identify and define. The economic approach will highlight the characteristics of the sector, its potential for the economic development of regions but also the risks it can entail. The course will provide a critical review of the virtuous-vicious relationship between tourism and culture. It will thus highlight the risks that tourism can entail (for example in terms of wear and tear of WH sites) but also the strategies that can be applied to avoid or, at least, reduce these risks.

Every week the lecturer will introduce a theme illustrating the main theoretical notions and some examples. The week after a group of students will lead the class making a presentation that provides a thorough analysis of the same topic using a case study.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to teach students the main concepts from the economics of tourism, considering the evolution and development of the sector through time, focusing in particularly on the niche of cultural tourism. Based on a critical engagement with the fundamental theories and empirical literature, students are challenged to identify and comment the effects, opportunities and challenges related to cultural tourism. Students will improve their presentation and writing skills by doing presentations in class and writing a final essay.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81117,2018,"Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture","Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Lavanga'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In academia, business environment and policy-making circles the past decade has given rise to a growing acknowledgment of the design industries as paradigmatic sectors of post-industrial economies, “cognitive-cultural” capitalism, or even better “neo-industrial” economies, in which production increasingly relies on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local specificities. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic, reading material, case studies and fieldtrips. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature, summarize it for discussion in class and apply it to specific cases. A critical approach is encouraged. Topics covered in the course, among others: characteristics of design products; demand for design products; economic and spatial organization of design industries; labour market for designers; intermediaries, temporary clusters and global pipelines; sustainability issues in design industries. Students will focus on design, fashion or architecture industries and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation. This course builds further upon the courses in Term 1 and 2, and it is connected to topics that students will encounter in their master thesis.

column2: • The maximum number of participants is 25.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The seminar will confront students with the most recent issues and theories linked to the design industries - in particular fashion, design and architecture. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the design industries. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course builds on Economics and Financing of Health Care, in which the principles of health economics and health care financing are explained. This course uses the tools and concepts discussed in that course to analyse and compare health and health care at the macro or system level. The performance of health care systems may be evaluated by analysing whether the outcomes are efficient and equitable. Therefore, this course consists of three parts.

The first part is about the relationships between health, health care and income. Understanding these relationships is an important goal in its own right, but also provides some of the building blocks that are necessary for the definition and measurement of equity (part 2) and efficiency (part 3). In each of the three parts, the main focus is on applying the analytical framework – and evaluating how other researchers’ applied it – to compare the performance of developed and less developed countries and discuss the aspects of health care systems and their performance in a structured manner.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain why equity and efficiency are important health system performance indicators
• Apply the tools that are used to measure equity and efficiency of health systems
• Judge whether the measures of equity and efficiency are used in a valid and meaningful way in international comparative analyses of health care system functioning
• Comment on scientific articles on health system performance from top journals in the field of health economics

<body>Game theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analyzing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organizations, and beyond. This course provides an inGame theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analyzing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organizations, and beyond. This course provides an introduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. The emphasis of the course is on developing skills to approach problems in a structured and systematic manner. The course aims to promote a careful approach to strategic situations, without undue emphasis on technicalities. The reading material assigned for this course is illustrative of the sort of game-theoretic reasoning this course seeks to promote. Prior knowledge of game theory is not required.troduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. column3: In deze module wordt ervan uitgegaan dat bestuurskunde- en sociologiestudenten een brede economische basis moeten krijgen omdat ze op verschillende wijze in aanraking kunnen komen met het vakgebied. Bestuurskundigen en sociologen krijgen voortdurend op verschillende plekken, bij departementen, gemeenten en organisaties, te maken met ontwikkelingen, projecten dan wel beleid, waarbij economische principes en instrumentarium toegepast worden om maatschappelijke processen te beïnvloeden. Daarbij komen vier aspecten aan bod:

column5: Micro-economisch gedachtengoed: consumentengedrag, producentengedrag, markt(werking), vraagsturing, collectieve goederen (plus externe effecten) en welvaartsverdelingsvraagstukken.

Macro-economisch gedachtengoed: Uitgaande van vraag- dan wel aanbodgericht beleid, gericht op allocatie, stabilisatie en verdeling, aandacht voor vormgeving en doeltreffendheid van economische politiek, monetair beleid, sociale zekerheid, verdelingsvraagstukken en internationale economische betrekkingen.
Begroting: Inkomsten en uitgaven, normen, besluitvormingsprocessen.
De betekenis van instituties, hun bijdrage aan economische ontwikkeling en economische politiek, en de samenhang tussen hun vormgeving en de effectiviteit van beleid.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: <mystyle>De module 'Economie: productie, verdeling, en de rol van de overhead' heeft tot doel studenten vertrouwd te maken met het economisch begrippenapparaat en deze kunnen toepassen op actuele maatschappelijke en beleidsmatige vraagstukken</mystyle></body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80500,2018,Economisch Beleid & Management Control,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. PK Marks', 'dr. SJ Keulen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het college Economisch Beleid & Management Control voor het avondprogramma Master Bestuurskunde heeft tot doel studenten een oriëntatie te geven op micro-economie, overheidsfinanciën en management control (bedrijfsvoering). De rode draad in deze module is het economisch beleid, waarbij de rol van de overheid met haar mogelijkheden en beperkingen centraal staat. Als publiek manager zal je sturing moeten geven aan economische problemen. Hierbij is het noodzakelijk om zowel de individuele economische afwegingen te begrijpen, als de (on)mogelijkheden die de overheidsfinanciën te kennen. Via management control kun je hierna beleid opstellen, budgetteren, uitvoeren, monitoren en verantwoorden.

Vragen die tijdens deze module aan de orde komen zijn o.a. hoe functioneren markten, hoe ga je om met schaarse middelen, welke rol speelt de overheid daarbij, hoe zit het begrotingsbeleid in elkaar, en hoe kan ik meten of het gevoerde beleid doeltreffend was.

Het onderwijsprogramma bevat afwisselende werkvormen als hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, en discussiebijeenkomsten. Het precieze rooster zal t.z.t. bekend worden gemaakt. Om met de collegestof te oefenen en later in de praktijk te kunnen brengen krijgen studenten ruim de gelegenheid zelf actuele casussen op te lossen. In het te schrijven paper komen de verschillende oriëntaties terug en laat de student zien dat hij de verschillende mechanismes uit micro-economie, overheidsfinanciën en economisch beleid kan analyseren.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student is in staat om kritisch te reflecteren op de begrippen en mechanismen uit de micro-economie.
• De student kan het micro-economisch instrumentarium, behorende bij de mechanismen, toepassen in beleid en de welvaartsafwegingen die daarbij horen analyseren.
• De student is in staat om te verklaren hoe keuzes gemaakt worden voor overheidsingrijpen, overheidsfinanciën en de omvang van de collectieve sector.
• De student is in staat om de functie van management control en de bijbehorende begrippen uit te leggen.
• De student is in staat om de verschillende mechanismen uit management control toe te passen op een casus.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81811,2018,Ecophilosophy: Beyond Sustainability and Environment,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['AWM Griffioen, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, we analyse the transition from a linear, oppositional, externalising, identity based discourse on ecology to a circular, inclusive discourse that is based on a ecophilosophical perspective, that focuses on differences and relations. Connecting the domain of arts, science and politics to philosophy, a threefold ecology (ECO3) is explored and fed back into the current debates on ecology. The broad perspective is the proposition that after the modern enlightenment of the mind 21<sup>st</sup> century schizoid man is up to a new medial enlightenment that acknowledges the productive role of technology for the constitution of our self-consciousness.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Acquiring a limited but relevant overview on current philosophical debates on sustainability and ecology and being able to analyze and debate specific ecophilosophical problems concerning the relation between economy, ethics, politics and ecology. To learn to carefully read, understand and critically reflect on selected texts of a diversity of authors that problematize conventional concepts, disclosing new perspectives on ecological issues focused on the transition of philosophy to ecosophy.</body>

column5: De student kan een goede samenwerking met en tussen leerlingen tot stand brengen.

De student kan relevante informatie uitwisselen met collega’s in de school en uitkomsten daarvan benutten.

De student kan eigen opvattingen over het leraarschap en de eigen bekwaamheden als leraar expliciteren, kritisch onderzoeken en verder ontwikkelen op basis van theoretische inzichten en empirische gegevens.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Vanaf het moment dat we geboren zijn tot aan het eind van ons leven,         blijft         de         mens         nieuwe         dingen         leren.         Soms         maken         we         ons         dingen         vrijwel         automatisch         eigen         en         soms         eist         het         een         extreme         inspanning.         Veel         van         dit         leren         gebeurt         in         een         onderwijssetting,         die         speciaal         ingericht         is         om         bepaalde         kennis         en         vaardigheden         bij         te         brengen.         Maar         hoe         gaat         dat         leren         nu         precies         in         zijn         werk?         Zijn         er         verschillende         vormen         van         leren         en         welke         vorm         is         dan         de         beste?         En         hoe         kun         je         in         je         onderwijs         het         leren         stimuleren?         Wanneer         gaat         dit         leren         fout?         Welke         leerproblemen         kom         je         tegen?         Waarom         kunnen         we         soms         dingen         die         we         geleerd         hebben         in         de         ene         context         wel         goed         toepassen         en         in         een         andere         context         niet?         Deze         en         nog         andere         vragen         over         leren         staan         centraal         in         dit         blok.         Studenten         denken         na         over         deze         vragen         aan         de         hand         van         problemen         uit         de         praktijk         van         onderwijs         en         onderzoek.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

Studenten zullen vertrouwd raken met thema's zoals leren lezen, misconcepties, transfer, expertise, leermotivatie, leren met multimedia, toetsing en de achtergronden bij het probleemgestuurd onderwijs. Er wordt bij elk van de thema's ook aandacht besteed aan implicaties voor de inrichting van onderwijs.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In de onderwijsgroepen wordt gewerkt met verschillende vignetten van somatische zieke patiënten (met of zonder psychische problemen). De hoorcolleges bieden elke week verbreding van het betreffende onderwerp. In de eerste week wordt aandacht besteed aan diagnostiek van psychische problemen bij somatisch zieke patiënten. Psychische problematiek kan het gevolg zijn van ziekte of het ziek zijn en het kan een complicerende factor zijn bij een somatische ziekte. Verder komt het verschil tussen stepped-care en matched-care aan bod. De voorwaarden voor beide worden besproken evenals de voor- en nadelen van deze twee methodieken.

De tweede week gaat over laagdrempelige en kortdurende behandelingen, zoals zelfhulp en e-mental health. Er zijn vele vormen van zelfhulp, zoals zelfhulpgroepen, zelfmanagementprogramma’s en bibliotherapie. Maar kan een behandeling zonder therapeut wel werken? De opkomst van nieuwe media biedt nieuwe mogelijkheden voor de hulpverlening. Zo wordt steeds vaker gebruikgemaakt van internet, e-mail, sms, chat en games in de psychologische hulpverlening. Hoe gaat dat?

In week drie komt een aantal vormen van psychologische behandeling bij somatische patiënten aan bod. Het doel is klachtvermindering en het verbeteren van de eigen gezondheid en kwaliteit van leven. We gaan in op cognitieve therapie, en daarbinnen specifiek op het gevolgenmodel. Op welke theorieën zijn deze behandelingen gebaseerd? Wat zijn de basisprincipes? Hoe werken deze therapieën? Wanneer kunnen ze worden ingezet?

Het beheersbaar houden van de kosten in de zorg staat hoog op de agenda van de overheid en de zorgverzekeraars. Dat betekent dat er wordt gekeken naar de verhouding tussen de effecten en de kosten van een behandeling. In week vier gaat het daarom over kosteneffectiviteit. Een ander onderwerp in deze week is de rol van non-specifieke factoren (zoals de duur van de therapie en de therapeutische relatie) bij psychologische behandelingen. Wat zijn deze factoren en hoe kan je ze beïnvloeden zodat een behandeling zo effectief mogelijk is?

In de vijfde week zijn we aanbeland bij meer intensievere behandelingen, zoals psychofarmacologie. Psychologen schrijven zelf geen pillen voor, maar het is belangrijk dat zij op de hoogte zijn van medische behandelmogelijkheden, hoe deze werken en wat de voor- en nadelen zijn.

Het practicum bestaat uit vier sessies, waarin je met je groep een (simulatie)patiënt met reuma en somberheidsklachten begeleidt. Je oefent o.a. het voeren van een intakegesprek en verschillende psychologische interventietechnieken. Op die manier doe je zoveel mogelijk ervaring op met technieken die je als therapeut kunt gebruiken. Ook heb je na afloop een overzicht van de verschillende fasen van het therapieproces (intake, behandelingsfase en afronding) en de specifieke eisen die elke fase stelt aan de therapeut.
Vanwege beperkte capaciteit kunnen maximaal 50 studenten deelnemen aan dit blok.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Dit keuzevak is bedoeld voor studenten psychologie die willen weten hoe psychologische behandelingen werken bij patiënten met lichamelijke klachten. Het is een introductie op behandelingen die door medisch psychologen kunnen worden ingezet. De medisch psycholoog werkt vanuit de visie dat somatische, psychologische en sociale aspecten bij elke aandoening een rol spelen. Vragen die o.a. aan bod komen zijn: Waarom zouden somatische patiënten eigenlijk gebaat kunnen zijn bij een psychologische behandeling? Voor welke patiënten is een psychologische behandeling geschikt (of noodzakelijk)? Welke vorm van psychologische behandeling biedt je een patiënt aan? Hoe motiveer je patiënten voor psychologische begeleiding? Wanneer kies je voor een psychologische behandeling en wanneer voor medicamenteuze therapie? Begin je standaard bij elke patiënt aan een eerstelijns psychologische behandeling, of kies je op basis van de kenmerken van de patiënt gelijk voor een tweede- of derdelijns zorgaanbod? Kan je nieuwe media en psychologische zorg combineren? Zo ja, hoe doe je dat? Werkt een psychologische behandeling eigenlijk wel? Zo ja, hoe werkt dat dan? Is het de theorie die ten grondslag ligt aan de therapie of is het de aandacht die je als cliënt krijgt van de therapeut? Hoe bepaal je of je behandeling heeft gewerkt? Na afloop van het blok heeft de student kennis opgedaan over indicatiecriteria voor verschillende psychologische behandelingen (voornamelijk psychologische interventies) die door medisch psychologen worden ingezet, de kenmerken en werkwijze van verschillende psychologische behandelingen en de effectieve bestanddelen ervan. Studenten kennen het principe van stepped-care en kunnen de voor- en nadelen daarvan uitleggen. Studenten zijn in staat om deze kennis toe te passen op praktische casuïstiek van patiënten met sterk uiteenlopende lichamelijke problemen die tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en practica aan bod komt.

Dit keuzevak is zowel interessant en geschikt voor studenten die de minor Medische Psychologie hebben gevolgd als voor studenten die (nog) weinig kennis hebben van het vakgebied van de medische psychologie.

column5: De student kan uitleggen wat de invloed van somatische aandoeningen kan zijn op het psychisch functioneren (en vice versa).
De student kan de stepped-care methodiek met de matched-care methodiek vergelijken.

De student kan aangeven welke verschillende behandelingen medisch psychologen kunnen gebruiken bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen, zoals (online) zelfhulp, cognitieve gedragstherapie en psychofarmacologie.
De student kan aangeven wat de mogelijkheden en onmogelijkheden zijn van verschillende behandelingen die medisch psychologen kunnen inzetten bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen
De student kan onderbouwen voor welke psychologische behandeling het beste gekozen kan worden bij een gefingeerde casus over een somatisch zieke patiënt met psychische problemen.
De student kan de basistechnieken van de cognitieve gedragstherapie benoemen en zelf toepassen bij een simulatiepatiënt.
De student kan benoemen en toelichten welke factoren bij psychologische behandelingen werkzaam zijn.

column2: </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: This course will provide a global outline of how the human body develops from a fertilised egg. From an embryological perspective human prenatal development can be grossly divided into three periods, i.e. the early pre-embryonic period covering the first two weeks, the embryonic period from 2 to 8 weeks after conception, and the fetal period that extends from the 9th week to birth (usually at 38 weeks after conception). This course will focus on the embryonic period. An important topic is related to the transformations during the 3th and 4th week of development when the early embryo transforms from a disk-like structure into a cylindrical embryo in which most body parts and organs are formed in rudimentary form. In most instances organs arise from transient embryonic structures. For instance, the central nervous systems derives from a tube-like structure termed the neural tube while the muscles and vertebral column derive from small segmented spherical structures termed ‘somites’ and the kidneys will arise from a structure termed ‘metanephros’. These temporary embryonic structures illustrate an important theme in development: i.e. the gradual increase of complexity of tissues, organs and the whole body. Another important theme in development is the constant crosstalk between adjacent cells and tissues to steer each others development. To communicate cells and tissues use a relatively limited molecular toolbox that including signalling molecules, cell-cell interaction proteins and transcription factors. Several examples of developmental molecular tools, and how they operate during the formation of the body plan and organogenesis will be provided.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course you will have basic knowledge of:

column5: Development of primordial germ cells, genital tract development and sexual differentiation
Early pre-implantation development
Sizes and gross appearance of the developing human body throughout pregnancy.

Development of the basic body plan, including the development of the major germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), the development of the body axes (cranio-caudal, left-right, dorso-ventral), the role of key embryonic events, i.e. gastrulation, neurulation and embryonic folding, and the role of temporary embryonic structures such as the primitive streak, the notochord, neural crest, pharyngeal arches, somites, and lateral plate mesoderm

The role of signalling molecules, such as Sonic hedgehog, BMPs and Wnts, and transcription regulators such as the Hox family of proteins in the regulation of developmental processes such as the development of limbs and the vertebral column.
How abnormalities in embryonic signalling cascades may result in congenital malformations

column2: </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: In this course we study emerging economies. This has become a popular theory since the end of the Cold War in the late 1980s. What exactly do we mean by emerging economies? Why and how do they develop? What are the effects of emerging economies on the global division of labour? This course takes a historical approach because the concept of emerging economies. Throughout world history we can discern the rise and decline of markets and economies. Before c. 1800 the economic centre of the world was firmly in Eastern Asia, but shifted to Western Europe and North America during the Industrial Revolution. We are now perhaps witnessing a new shift with the rise of the BRIC-countries: Brazil, Russia, India and China. These important economic processes also change the balance of economic and military power in the world and thus the system of international relations.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: - Students can define and discuss the concept of emerging economies.

column4: - Students can apply the concept of emerging economies to various historical cases.

column3: - Students can compare emerging economies in different regions of the world and through time.

column4: - Students can write and present a speech, review and newspaper article, organize a debate, and a case of an emerging economy.

During the lectures, we cover the relevant material and students discuss papers related to the specific technique. The course also provides an introduction to Stata through class examples and the use of real datasets.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is structured around current and emerging themes and debates in the methodological literature. Current research routines and their alternatives will be discussed and critically assessed using literature in which competing approaches are presented and justified or criticized.
(a) Read literature on methodological debates and discuss its contents in class.
(b) Practice your understanding of this literature by means of assignments.

For each of the ten plenary sessions, there will be readings and an assignment. You will receive feedback on each assignment. Submission of assignments (before the stated deadline) and attendance at the sessions are mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to strengthen and deepen the understanding of the core methodological issues and choices in empirical research. The contents of this course comprise all phases of an empirical study, from the specification of its aim against the background of an evaluation of previous research, through case selection and measurement decisions, to the production of the study’s results, their interpretation and their reporting.</body>

This course deals with factors that influence learning, such as characteristics of the learner, characteristics of the learner's environment, and the learning process. Topics that we will focus on include individuals’ intellectual capacities and how intelligence contributes to learning, the influence of the family and the importance of upbringing in relation to learning, teachers’ role in the learning process and what he/she can do to motivate students. Moreover, we will learn how learners can influence their learning outcomes. For this, we will look at self-directed learning, which is an important learning skill, and physical movement and exercise as a means to support learning.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Telling entertaining stories to educate people is as old as mankind. Think of court jesters, fairytales, puppet shows: all examples of entertainment with an added value. Nowadays you find it in all modern media: drama and soap series on television, blogs on the internet, „webisodes‟ on your mobile phone. The difference with the old age is that because of the application of modern technology, the potential impact of an Entertainment-Education intervention is much bigger.

The Entertainment-Education strategy is a communication strategy that has received a lot of scientific attention (both nationally and internationally), and is being put into practice more and more often. To effectively apply this strategy, it is important to gain knowledge and skills both in academic and applied settings and beyond. In this course we discuss and show examples of EE programs, theories for social change, media practice, different EE collaborations, formative and summative research and ethics.  During the course you gain knowledge and experience via (guest) lectures, analyzing video and film fragments, and working in small groups on designing an Entertainment Education media program.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course gives you an in-depth understanding of the Entertainment-Education (EE) strategy and how it works in theory and practice. Entertainment-Education is a scientific communication strategy that systematically interweaves prosocial issues into an entertainment storytelling format in order to create a favorable climate for prosocial change. We will apply participatory working methods to actively engage you on your Entertainment-Education journey and to show how you can use your learning experience in your future professional life.
You have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • The main theoretical approaches and perspectives on the Entertainment-Education for Social Change communication strategy.

• Examples of how various Entertainment-Education media formats are designed and implemented worldwide (e.g. in soap- and drama series, webisodes, serious games, music, theater cross media and transmedia platforms).

• How prosocial organizations, communication experts, entertainment media makers and other stakeholders collaborate during the design and implementation of an entertainment education program e.g. in the field of health, sustainability and social tolerance.
• Different forms of Entertainment-Education research that come into play during the development and implementation of an EE media format.
• Potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects that might be faced.
• Analyze the applications of Entertainment-Education (EE) strategies worldwide and EE-formats in different media.
• Apply theoretical notions of the EE strategy (e.g. social learning theory, elaboration likelihood model, para-social interaction, positive deviance strategy).
• Identify and understand different roles of various stakeholders in the design and implementation of an Entertainment-Education media format.
• Apply different forms of EE research.
• Examine and (pro-actively) reflect on potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects in Entertainment-Education programs.
• Design and pitch an Entertainment-Education media intervention plan.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80720,2018,Entrepreneurial Finance and FinTech,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['A Schwienbacher', 'R Ozturk - Ankomah, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of the course is to present the theory and practice of the financing of entrepreneurial firms. Special attention will be devoted to understanding the motivations of the different players involved (mainly investors and entrepreneurs) and how to reconcile their interests through proper deal structuring. Next to more traditional sources of entrepreneurial finance such as business angel and venture, the course also offers a special focus on different forms of crowdfunding, which involves raising funds through the Internet, and how entrepreneurial finance is currently affected by digitalization.
Lectures build on theory and case studies that will be discussed in class.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Know more about different forms of entrepreneurial finance, including crowdfunding
• Understand financing techniques used in new ventures
• Understand the processes used in incubating and growing a new venture from a financial perspective
• Understand the design of contracting structures for young ventures
• Get some insights into the valuation of new ventures

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83101,2018,Entrepreneurial Skillset,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. MN Cholakova'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Running a start-up requires operating under high uncertainty and navigating well through often chaotic, confusing information and experiences. In this course, we will focus on the customer development process, after an opportunity has been identified, and address a set of skills that can help early-stage entrepreneurs to manage their ventures more effectively. In particular, we will discuss different leadership styles and decision making approaches and explore how these can affect the performance, motivation and culture of the members of a new venture. We will further focus on strategies for making good decisions and discuss ways to avoid common mistakes and biases throughout the customer development journey. Being an effective entrepreneur and leader will also require learning how to develop empathy and to engage effectively with your customer, by acquiring strong interviewing techniques. As an entrepreneur, you would also often need to handle difficult conversations and we will further identify a set of techniques for effective conflict resolution, as well as a range of influence tactics and mechanisms that can be applied in your start-up and work relationships. In addition, we will discuss different negotiation styles and learn how best to align individuals’ goals, interests and values with those of the organization. The overall aim of the course is to provide practical knowledge and skills that future entrepreneurs can apply when developing, testing and validating their hypotheses about a business opportunity.
Course Format – Action Learning and Reflective Exercises

The teaching philosophy for this course is based on action learning and reflection. Students are thus expected to develop a hands-on approach to the themes covered in the course. Active class participation is highly recommended as the lectures are intended to offer practical insight and an opportunity to directly apply the new skills.

Learning from the course is greatly enhanced when everyone is able to contribute and collectively share knowledge and experience with the different topics.  It is your responsibility to come to class fully prepared. To facilitate your learning, you are expected to contribute to class discussions, ask questions, express opinions, draw linkages among cases and theories, and develop new ideas.

We will selectively discuss key constructs and ideas from each class’ reading list and, where applicable, the respective case assignment. The purpose of this course is to help you develop some of the skills that we will address in each session, backed by a set of readings and applied examples from the cases. This means that in class, we will largely try to focus on applying the theory by means of engaging you in simulations, role plays, team exercises, etc. Hence, it is your responsibility to have prepared the readings and worked through the cases, as they will not necessarily be discussed in each class in a step-by-step fashion. Your knowledge of the relevant literature will be evaluated based on your reflective assignments and team projects.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand the dynamics of the entrepreneurial process and learn best practices for customer development.
<li>
Recognize and practice different strategies for effective decision making and identify the factors and specific approaches that can help you make better decisions for your start-up.
<li>
Gain insight into how to develop empathy and apply it into your customer development process.
<li>
Practice and learn a set of different leadership characteristics and styles and analyze how each can have a distinct impact on start-up teams’ motivation, commitment, and culture.
<li>
Analyze and apply a set of negotiation techniques and learn how to apply them in order to improve your start-up’s outcomes.
<li>
Identify the right balance of roles, rewards and relationships when managing your team.
<li>
Learn how to deal with conflict and manage difficult employees by applying a set of conflict resolution techniques.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80780,2018,Entrepreneurial challenge I,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FPH Jaspers', 'M Bax']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Master in Management program kicks off with a brief but intensive Entrepreneurial Challenge module. In this pressure cooker module you will explore and experience what it entails to start a new and ambitious company. You will come to understand that not only existing businesses, but also new businesses require management. As you enter the Master in Management program, it is important to understand that without businesses there is nothing to manage, and without entrepreneurs there would be (and will be) no businesses. Furthermore, many students  from  RSM  Erasmus  University  will - at  some  stage  in  their  career - consider entrepreneurship  as  a  serious  career opportunity.

This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will develop and revise their own startup opportunities and explore viable business models. Entrepreneurship is about turning unmet needs and unsolved problems into viable economic activity. The essence of entrepreneurship has been described as ‘the pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources currently controlled.’ Entrepreneurship starts with the discovery of promising opportunities. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for startup entrepreneurs and existing companies alike to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value from the identified opportunities. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mindset. In this module you develop that mindset by exploring the first stages of the process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models.

The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication.

Successful completion of this course requires teamwork. Program management is responsible for the formation of teams. Teams are responsible for their internal processes. Overall, teams are expected to work professionally, ethically, and independently. Amongst others, free-riding should be addressed by each team at the start of the course (details will be provided on blackboard). Severe and/or repeated failure to adhere to the team process should be pointed out to the free-riding student as soon as possible. This should be done by e-mail with a cc. to all team members as well as the course coordinator. If this does not help, the free rider may be excluded from the course.

The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. Please note that the lecturer in this course will serve primarily as a coach, more so than as teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.

Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory. If you are set to miss a session, you have to inform the course coordinator by e-mail well in advance when and why you will miss the session. Unauthorized absence will affect the student’s individual grade. Each unauthorized missed class will result in a reduction of the final course grade of 0.25 points.
A document with the details of the schedule will be made available on Blackboard.
Grading for this course has two components:

column2: • New venture creation process report (80% of the final course grade; a team grade).
• Presentation of the final business plan (20% of the final course grade; a team grade).

column1: A document with the exact details of each component will be made available on Blackboard.
This course is worth 2 ECTS (1 foundation ECT and 1 master ECT).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • You will come to understand that new venture creation is a process to systematically turn business model assumptions into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.

• You will come to understand the complexity of the new venture creation process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
• You will develop the capability to construct, evaluate, and refine business models for new ventures.
• You will develop the capability to set-up effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
• You will develop the capability to document your business modelling process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.

• You will develop the capability to discuss and present your new venture creation process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in a feedback session with startup coaches and entrepreneurs, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80821,2018,Entrepreneurial challenge II,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. FPH Jaspers'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Last year’s Entrepreneurial Challenge I focused on the development of real-life independent startups. In this follow-up, pressure cooker course you will explore the world of intrapreneurship. You will come to understand that existing, large companies require systematic management of their growth and innovation strategies, which includes intrapreneurship. In today’s dynamic business environment, it is important to understand that without intrapreneurship and corporate entrepreneurship today’s established organizations are highly likely to be disrupted sooner rather than later. Furthermore, many students  from  RSM  Erasmus  University  will - at  some  stage  in  their  career - consider corporate entrepreneurship and new business development as a serious career opportunity. Very similarly, many students will enter a position as a strategy/business analyst. Although the role of business analyst contains a lot of diverse tasks depending on the company, it has in common that huge and diverse data sources must be analyzed and that a course of action must be recommended. To this end this course will train students to employ a validation board during their project work.

This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of corporate entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will explore the impact of new technologies, in particular fintech, on established business models, in particular in the logistics sector, and set out to discover new digital business and growth opportunities.

The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work, such as conducting key stakeholder interviews on-site. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of corporate entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing new business and/or renewal opportunities and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication during this team-based course.

Successful completion of this course requires teamwork. The course participants are responsible themselves for forming teams of five students. To the extent that teams of five students are not formed by students themselves before and during the first session, programme management and the course coordinator will complete and/or form teams right after the first session. Teams are responsible for their internal processes. Overall, teams are expected to work professionally, ethically, and independently. Amongst others, free-riding should be addressed by each team at the start of the course (details will be provided on blackboard). Severe and/or repeated failure to adhere to the team process should be pointed out to the free-riding student as soon as possible. This should be done by e-mail with a cc. to all team members as well as the course coordinator. If this does not help, the free rider may be excluded from the course.

The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions, to a market place. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. Please note that the lecturer in this course will serve primarily as a coach, more so than as teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.

Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory. If you are set to miss a session, you have to inform the course coordinator by e-mail well in advance when and why you will miss the session. Unauthorized absence will affect the student’s individual grade. Each unauthorized missed class will result in a reduction of the final course grade of 0.25 points.
Grading for this course has two components:

column2: • Process report (80% of the final course grade; a team grade).
• Presentation of the final report (20% of the final course grade; a team grade).

column1: A document with the exact details of each component will be made available on Blackboard.
This course is worth 2 ECTS (1 foundation ECTS and 1 master ECTS).</body>

column2: • You will come to understand that opportunity creation is a process to systematically generate business model assumptions and to turn them into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change, be it in the context of an independent startup or a corporate startup.

• You will come to understand the complexity of new business development and corporate entrepreneurship, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplenary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.

column1: Analytical skills: During this course you will develop fundamental skills of professional business analysis, such as:

column2: • the capability to explore, discover and create opportunities at the intersection of new technologies and industries.

• the capability to collect and process numerous and diverse sources of information to scout and evaluate new growth opportunities to complement the business models and growth portfolios of established organizations.
• You will develop the capability to document your intrapreneurial process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.

• You will develop the capability to discuss, present, and pitch your intrapreneurship process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in feedback sessions, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session (Get in the Ring style).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80176,2018,Entrepreneurial finance & private equity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. PGJ Roosenboom'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The objective of this course is to provide students with a state-of-the-art understanding of the valuation of small and mid-cap public and private firms, and the economics of contracts as it applies to entrepreneurship and new venture finance. Entrepreneurship concerns the undertaking of new business ventures. We will analyse the unique financial issues relating to entrepreneurial firms and to develop a set of skills that has wide applications for such situations. Specific topics will include: start-up ventures; financial management of rapidly growing firms; deal structuring; valuation; initial public offerings; the decision to harvest; and leveraged/management buyouts. We will discuss the various sources of capital for entrepreneurial firms. These sources include venture capital, commercial banks and crowd funding. The decisions of firms at various phases of their life cycle will be examined and the advantages and disadvantages of various sources of financing will be compared. Analytical tools will be introduced and utilized. Financial analysis, various valuation methods, negotiations, and deal structuring are examined in the context of entrepreneurial firms. This course is aimed at students who plan to start, acquire, finance or work for entrepreneurial, fast-growing businesses. It will also be useful for students who plan to join venture capital/private equity firms and investment banks. The course aims at instructing the student in how “real world” professional investors and corporate managers operate to create wealth from entrepreneurial activity.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After having followed this course, students are among others able to understand how to value a start-up firm, how contracts used in new venture finance shape incentives, how deals are structured, how to finance young start-up companies, how private equity works in creating value in start-ups, buyouts and growth financing and how to decide when to exit investments. Students are also able to appraise and construct a valuation for a start-up company, compare and select the different sources of financing and connect theory and practice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

If you want to know more about developing a business model for a startup and/or setting up your own venture, the Entrepreneurial Lab course is for you. Within an intense and hand-on experiential approach, the Entrepreneurial Lab course allows you exploring a business opportunity with your team and testing its potential value.

This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the role, the analytics, and the process of business planning that leads to the successful creation of new ventures. We bring in guest lecturers and practitioners to provide lectures and workshops. Above all, students will be responsible to develop their own professional networks. As it’s a hands-on course, you will learn about business modelling, how to refine opportunities, analyse feasibility, financial planning, and organisational implementation. You will write a weekly blog and a business report and pitch your idea to a jury of experts. In previous years our students launched successful new businesses, including Senz Umbrellas, Symbid and Yoursurprise.com.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
know what elements make up a start-up business model, and they will understand how (and to what extent) these elements interrelate.
<li>
understand the inherent uncertain and iterative nature of the business modelling process.
<li>

be able to apply numerous tools and techniques to develop a comprehensive and coherent value proposition and business model that provides a clear and actionable point of departure for the ambitious entrepreneur.
<li>

be able to develop and discuss their arguments and findings in a multidisciplinary student team as well as in a professional context of business relationships (e.g., mentors, investors, internal stakeholders, etc.).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domains of entrepreneurship theory and research and offers a practical experience to get a taste of entrepreneurship. After all, entrepreneurship is about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.

In this course module, you will approach entrepreneurship from theoretical, practical and applied perspectives. During the first three weeks the topics of entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship will be discussed from an academic point of view. Running parallel to the PBL sessions, the first two lectures are designed to provide information for your individual research paper. Starting with the first workshop in week 3, the remainder of the course will focused on entrepreneurship from a practical point of view. During the workshops at EUC and feedback sessions at ECE, you will receive input for your practical assignment, which challenges you and your team to develop a business model of your own.
As such, this course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a new venture.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain what entrepreneurship is, what its central elements are, and why entrepreneurship is crucial for our economy and society;
• Explain the difference between entrepreneurship and management in general, and between entrepreneurship, intrapreneurship and social entrepreneurship in particular.
• Develop a business model by applying the principles of the lean startup method.
• Explain how new ventures emerge and develop.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80686,2018,Entrepreneurship,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AJ Hofman', 'dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'dr. RM Bakker', 'PJ de Wilde - Mes', 'THJ Geradts, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Entrepreneurship staat voor zelfstandig gedrag; het gaat om durf, creativiteit en bovenal initiatief. Volgens Timmons (1989) kan ondernemerschap daarom gedefinieerd worden als: “…de capaciteit om iets te scheppen en op te bouwen vanuit praktisch niets. Het gaat om initiëren, doen, en het opbouwen van een onderneming of organisatie, in plaats van toekijken, analyseren en het beschrijven ervan. Het is de fijne neus voor het waarnemen van kansen waar anderen chaos, tegenstelling en verwarring zien”. Niet alleen illustreren de groten der aarde zoals Bill Gates, Richard Branson en Muhammad Yunus hoe een dergelijke definitie van ondernemerschap tot uiting komt, maar bewijzen 1,5 miljoen Nederlandse bedrijven dat er volop mogelijkheden zijn om door middel van ondernemerschap je eigen wereld te creëren.
Sterker nog: het aantal nieuwe bedrijven in Nederland blijft steeds verder stijgen waardoor men rustig kan stellen dat er kansen genoeg zijn voor aspirerende ondernemers.

Afgezien van een algemene stijging in het aantal bedrijven is het vooral bijzonder dat steeds meer jongeren onder de twintig zich bij de KvK registreren. Wat maakt ondernemerschap onder Nederlandse jongeren aantrekkelijk? De voornaamste redenen zijn extra verantwoordelijkheid, ondernemerschap als alternatief voor grote multinationals, meer bewustzijn en als belangrijkste reden een verandering in de algemene mentaliteit die overeenkomt met welbekende tips van ondernemers zoals “Start young!” en “Just do it!”. Opvallend is dat ongeveer de helft van alle Nederlandse studenten aangeeft een eigen bedrijf te willen starten, echter laten cijfers van het Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship (2015) tegelijkertijd zien dat slechts 6% van alle Nederlandse studenten ook daadwerkelijk onderneemt. Kan men daarom stellen dat ondernemerschap niet voor iedereen is weggelegd?

Wij zijn ervan overtuigd dat in principe ieder persoon op zijn manier ondernemend kan zijn. Om deze reden willen we studenten de kans bieden om erachter te komen of er ook daadwerkelijk een ondernemer in hun schuilt. Naast het verkennen van ondernemerschap als academische discipline zal daarom een praktische kennismaking met ondernemerschap centraal staan. Ongeacht of studenten na afloop van deze cursus beginnen met ondernemen, zeker is dat de toekomst meer persoonlijk ondernemerschap zal vereisen omdat we met steeds minder vastigheid te maken krijgen en ontwikkelingen om ons heen steeds sneller zullen gaan. Een oriëntatie op ondernemen is daarom hoe dan ook een must voor de eenentwintigste--eeuwse professional. Kortom, het vak Entrepreneurship…
1) … verschaft een algemene introductie op regulier ondernemerschap, sociaal ondernemerschap en intern ondernemerschap als wetenschappelijke discipline.
2) … laat studenten op een actieve manier kennismaken met ondernemerschap door middel van de RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge.
3) ... stimuleert studenten om ondernemender te worden door middel van inspirerende gastcolleges, kritische reflecties, prikkelende interactieve werkcolleges en de RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge.

Na de cursus zijn studenten bekend met diverse vormen van ondernemerschap en een breed scala aan actuele onderwerpen die van belang zijn bij de start van een eigen bedrijf. Ook zal tijdens dit vak in het bijzonder de nadruk liggen op de ontwikkeling van diverse belangrijke academische vaardigheden.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van de hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, essayopdrachten en het verdiepingsonderzoek in trimester 5, kan de student:

column2: • Uitleggen wat ondernemerschap is, wat de kernelementen zijn, en waarom ondernemerschap als onmisbaar wordt gezien in onze economie en samenleving;
• De verschillen uitleggen tussen ondernemerschap en management in het algemeen en tussen regulier ondernemerschap, intern ondernemerschap en sociaal ondernemerschap in het bijzonder;
• De aard, rol en functies van de verschillende typen ondernemers en hun ondernemingen benoemen (regulier ondernemers, interne ondernemers, sociaal ondernemers)

• Kritisch de belangrijkste redenen en motieven analyseren die ten grondslag liggen aan het starten van een nieuw bedrijf, het initiëren van nieuwe bedrijvigheid binnen een gevestigd bedrijf, en het starten van een sociale onderneming;
• Benoemen hoe motivaties en drijfveren van ondernemers tot uiting komen;
• Op een actieve en semiprofessionele manier participeren in discussies en literatuur toepassen tijdens discussies en opdrachten m.b.t. de in het vak behandelde onderwerpen;
• Op basis van voorgeschreven literatuur een goed onderbouwd en gestructureerd essay vervaardigen dat aan de in deze cursus gestelde richtlijnen van academisch schrijven voldoet;
• Kwalitatief onderzoek verrichten op basis van een zelf gemotiveerde onderzoeksvraag.

column1: Na afloop van de hoorcolleges, werkcolleges en de RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge in trimester 6, kan de student:

column2: • Een bedrijfsmodel ontwikkelen en de Lean Startup methode toepassen;
• Expliciteren hoe een individu zich kan ontwikkelen tot een (succesvol) ondernemer; hoe men een bedrijf opzet; en hoe dit bedrijf zich met goed gevolg kan ontwikkelen;
• Een sterke “elevator pitch” produceren voor zijn of haar onderneming;
• Op een creatieve manier met beperkte tijd presenteren door enkel afbeeldingen te gebruiken;

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81162,2018,Erasmus and Grotius on Islam and Judaism,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. E Rabbie'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Although Desiderius Erasmus (Rotterdam, 1466 [?] – Basel, 1536) as a humanist and student of religion was primarily and almost exclusively interested in Christianity, and thus never systematically occupied himself with the two other monotheistic religions that were known to him, Judaism and Islam, there is a fairly large number of passages in his works that deal critically with these two religions. After a short introduction on Erasmus’ life and works, the main attention during this course will be focused on reading a selection of relevant original texts from Erasmus’ works (in English translation).

Almost exactly one century after Erasmus, another Dutch humanist, Hugo Grotius (Delft, 1583 – Rostock, 1645) , called ‘the second Erasmus’ by some of his contemporaries, wrote a defense of Christian religion (On the Truth of Chistian Religion, 1627), in which he attempted a systematical ‘refutation’ of both Judaism and Islam. The second half of the course– again, after a general introduction to the author – will be devoted to a study of this book.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The student will become familiar with two important figures of 16th and 17th centuries European Christian humanism, Erasmus and Grotius, with special emphasis on their views of Islam and Judaism. The student will also become familiar with some of the key texts of both scholars on this subject (in English translation), thus learning to interpret an ancient text in its historical context.

<body>Het essay dient als sluitstuk voor studenten die een minor volgen van 15 CR. Na de vakken:

column2: • Fiscaal ondernemersrecht (4CR)
• Fiscaal concernrecht (4CR)
• Privaat en ondernemingsrecht (4CR)

column1: kunnen met dit afsluitende essay nog 3 CR behaald worden. Er kan in overleg met de coordinator een onderwerp worden gekozen, waarna de paper geschreven kan worden.Gekozen onderwerpen dienen verband te houden met een of meer van de gevolgde vakken.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Het onderkennen van een fiscaal probleem
• De werking van verschillende heffingswetten, en de economische en juridische gevolgen van gemaakte keuzes op het terrein van privaat en ondernemingsrecht kennen.
• Het kunnen beschrijven van een fiscaal probleem en de economische gevolgen vanuit verschillende heffingswetten, rekening houdend met de mogelijkheden van het privaat en ondernemingsrecht.
• Het formuleren van oplossingen voor de uitgewerkte problematiek.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81812,2018,Essential Contemporary Challenges: Philosophy and Practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. GH van Oenen'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We will discuss four key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’. We will explore their implications on both the individual and on the collective level. The four challenges are: 1) Enlightenment as emancipation: a blessing or a burden? The pressures of modern living. 2) democracy: do we need more, or less? Can democracy deliver on its promises – and can the citizens keep up? 3) biopolitics: is government turning biotechnological? Will government again become ‘racist’? And finally 4) transparency: how do we deal with Big Data, algorithmic decisionmaking, and more generally the ‘black box society’? How to think about nudging? Is more transparency the answer? We will try to derive answers from the work of contemporary philosophers such as Zizek, Rancière, Foucault.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Small scale weekly seminars, 1 x 2 hours (obligatory for full-time philosophy students, optional for double degree students)
Ability to assess the practical dimension inherent in philosophical theories on society and culture;
Ability to discuss case studies philosophically;
Ability to analyse, reflect and take a position on 4 societal issues discussed during the course and identify philosophical arguments and positions with respect to them.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84281,2018,Essentials of Auditing,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,,,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This module has the objective to give the participants an introduction into the principles of EU customs law, the build-up of current customs legislation (Union Customs Code, UCC) and its international background (WTO/WCO). Furthermore the basic principles of EU law and how this relates to national law systems will be discussed. Finally the role of case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) for customs law will be discussed, including how to read, understand and apply this case law.

column2: • Principles and structure of EU customs system;
• Customs & Trade – legislative framework, UCC;
• EU law and its relation to national law
• International Customs Law (WTO/WCO) and European Law;
• Legislation of the EU and case law of the CJEU, reading, understanding and applying it;

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the module the student must be able to:
1. Understand the structure and principles of the legislative framework of customs law, the student is able to explain the principles of customs law;
2. Understand the impact of EU law on national law, the student can explain the relationship between these two levels of law and is able to give a presentation on a specific customs case of the CJEU.

3. Understand the impact of international law on EU and national law; the student can explain the relationship between these two levels of law and is able to give a presentation on a specific customs case of the European Court of Justice dealing with this relationship.
4. Apply legislation and case law on specific practical situations.
5. Understand which customs regimes can be applied in the supply chain.
