https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81857,2018,Ethical Aspects of Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['MG Napolitano', 'OC Dede, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Economics and ethical questions are intertwined in many ways. In this course, we will shed light on and critically discuss the ethical presumptions economists hold. We will investigate how being explicit about the ethical aspects of economics can deepen our understanding of economics and its applications to policy making. First, we will analyze some of the key concepts in economics that embed ethical underpinnings such as rationality, preferences, efficiency, freedom, and welfare. Second, we will address the ethical evaluation of markets and a key instrument of contemporary public policy, nudge. Throughout the lectures and discussion seminars, we will discuss problems such as individual and corporate moral responsibility, and markets for human kidneys where the ethical aspects of economics come to the fore.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After successful completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1. Describe, clarify, and analyze the ethical underpinning of some key notions in economics such as efficiency, rationality, preferences, freedom, and welfare,
2. Apply the ethical insights to appraise a key economic institution (markets) and a contemporary policy instrument (nudge),
3. Formulate their own ethical evaluations of specific cases such as measurement of wellbeing, regulation or ban of specific markets
4. Defend their opinions in clear, argumentative short essays and engage in fruitful discussion with their peers.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81847,2018,Ethics and Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CB Binder'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.

column2: • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.
• You will be equipped to do research (e.g. for a Master’s dissertation) on questions of economic ethics, both theoretical/conceptual as well as applied questions.

• This course will help you to improve your knowledge of methods and styles of arguments in analytical moral philosophy (esp. ethics/normative political philosophy) – which can also be useful for other streams within analytical moral philosophy.

• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your writing and argumentation skills for analytical practical philosophy. This will be a special focus of this course, since you will receive detailed and extensive individual feedback on your written pieces of work.
• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your oral argumentation and presentation skills in moral philosophy, through participating in the class discussions.
• You will be able to learn/practice/rehearse some basic skills related to literature searching and use of libraries and bibliographical search methods.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80721,2018,Ethics and Stewardship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['AW Newton'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This is primarily a course about the ethical obligations of finance professionals, and the practical skills and strategies you need in order to remain true to your values in the face of workplace challenges. We also lay the groundwork for the later course on sustainable finance by exploring the idea of stewardship in its various forms: as ESG risk management, and as a norm.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

On successful completion of this module, students will have a thorough comprehension of the relevance of, core concepts and approaches to financial ethics, as well as an introductory understanding of the core concepts in investment stewardship e.g. they can:

column2: • Explain fundamental concepts in stewardship including power, legitimacy, stakeholders, and human rights
• Summarize normative and instrumental rationales for responsible behaviour in the financial industry including ethical, financial, and power-political arguments
• Recognize and explain novel ethical challenges to management in the finance setting

column1: On successful completion of this module, students will have the proven ability to apply advanced knowledge and related management concepts to the finance setting, e.g. they can:

column2: • Critically assess ethical issues in finance and strategize solutions to them in practical terms
• Analyse and script ethical arguments;
• Analyse the impacts of a firm by means of stakeholder analysis.

column1: On successful completion of this module, students can transfer these concepts and methods to typical management situations in the financial industry, e.g. they can:

column2: • Express and remain true to their values in the face of workplace challenges by utilizing practical skills and strategies
• Contribute to environmental, social and governance (ESG) risk perspectives to managerial and investment decision-making

E.M. Bunnik', 'dr. L.L.E. Bolt', 'dr. S. van de Vathorst', ""H. Ismaili M'hamdi"", 'J. Specker', 'M. Smedinga', 'mr. J.G.M. Aartsen', 'N. Aarts, MSc', 'prof. dr. I.D. de Beaufort', 'prof. dr. M.H.N. Schermer', 'Y.H. Stol']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81820,2018,"Ethiek, rationaliteit en emotie I",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. PJJ Delaere'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Welke rol spelen emoties in de morele oordeelsvorming van mensen? Zijn emoties constitutief voor de morele positie die mensen innemen of zijn het stoorzenders die een redelijke oordeelsvorming in de weg staan? En: wat zijn emoties? Zijn emoties louter gevoelens en is een moreel oordeel daarom altijd de expressie van een bepaald gevoel? Of zijn emoties ook te beschouwen als cognitieve mentale toestanden die ons informatie verschaffen over onszelf en over de wereld om ons heen? Ter beantwoording van deze vragen zullen we in deze cursus niet alleen de meest actuele moraalfilosofische debatten over ethiek, rationaliteit en emoties bespreken, maar ook te rade gaan bij het hedendaagse moraalwetenschappelijke onderzoek naar de oorsprong en aard van emoties en naar de invloed van emoties bij oordeelsvorming (o.m. werk van Frans de Waal, Jonathan Haidt en Antonio Damasio). We zullen nadenken over de lichamelijke basis van gevoelens en emoties en dit verbinden met cognitief psychologisch onderzoek naar de onmisbare (en soms misleidende) rol van emoties in het redeneren en het vormen van een standpunt. Vervolgens zullen we discussiëren over wat dit betekent voor de aard en de betrouwbaarheid van evaluatieve oordelen. Een morele stellingname is meer dan de expressie van een gevoel. Maar in welke zin is het meer en anders?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Inzicht verkrijgen in de belangrijkste hedendaagse moraalfilosofische en moraalwetenschappelijke visies en debatten over de aard van emoties en over de rol van emoties en redenen in morele oordeelsvorming; het op basis van dit inzicht ontwikkelen van een eigen standpunt ten aanzien van enkele cruciale kwesties in de morele psychologie en meta-ethiek.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85356,2018,Ethnographic Research and Reflexivity in Development Contexts,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. RBC Huijsmans'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The course is designed for those considering using an ethnographic research orientation (in whatever form) in their research paper and/or future career. For this purpose the course is divided into two blocks. The first block deals with a range of historical, epistemological and theoretical issues underpinning ethnography in the context of development research. In the second block the focus shifts to practice. In this block, course participants will evaluate the use of ethnography in past ISS research papers, carry out their own ethnographic research projects and reflect on these, and think through a range of practical, methodological and ethical issues pertaining to employing an ethnographic orientation in their anticipated RP projects.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The objectives of the course are three-fold. First, course participants will explore, discuss and come to understand some key epistemological debates underpinning ethnographic approaches to knowledge generation in the context of development, such as those pertaining to ‘situated knowledges’, ‘positionality of the researcher’, and debates on ‘place’ and ‘connections’. Second, course participants will get acquainted with conducting ethnographic research, and reflect on various dimensions of such practices, including participant observation, ethnographic approaches to qualitative methods, and the writing and interpretation of field notes. Third, course participants will develop an argued position on the (im)possibilities and particularities of ethnography in their own Research Paper plans, including its role, its feasibility, the researcher’s positionality, research ethics, and the methodological shape it may take.

column2: </body>

column1:
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82502,2018,Ethnographic Research and Reflexivity in Development Contexts,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. RBC Huijsmans'],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81104,2018,Ethnographic Research into Culture Participation,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. EH Bisschop Boele'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Central in the course is the discussion of two strands of literature. The first strand will focus on the elements of ethnographic research. We will read and discuss literature on data collection, data analysis, theoretical backgrounds (the interpretive research traditions, practice theory), and specific ethnographic/ethnography-related traditions such as auto-ethnography or grounded theory. This will be combined with the reading of examples of ethnographic research into culture participation. During the course, specific assignments will be given to practice the various elements of ethnographic research. In the meetings, students will be involved in active discussion as well as practical exercises in, e.g., interviewing and the open coding of ethnographic data. Students carry out a small ethnographic research project of their own choice, which is prepared through various assignments and which will be reported upon in the final essay. The course will provide a firm introduction into the topic and a sound basis for those who wish to carry out ethnographic or ethnograpically inspired research in the future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide students with an introductory but thorough understanding of ethnographic research into culture participation. Students will read and discuss key literature on the theoretical backgrounds and methodological issues of ethnographic research. This will be combined with a discussion of examples of ethnographic research into cultural participation. Students will be asked to carry out and report on individual research activities connected to the three main data sources in ethnography (observation, interview, study of documents/artefacts); this will feed into their final assignment, which will be the production of an essay based on the analysis of own empirical data.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81154,2018,Europe in a Globalizing World: Migration, Citizenship and Identity",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CSM Hull, PhD', 'G van Campenhout, MSc', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family to become 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship; (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.

Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>By the end of the class, the students will be able to

column2: • Illustrate and explain areas of EU’s activity in the world
• Compare different means of EU’s foreign affairs activity
• Contrast EU’s approaches in different areas of foreign policy
• Critically evaluate EU’s efficiency in global governance and foreign affairs

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80382,2018,European Integration: An Interdisciplinary Perspective,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. CWA van Wijnbergen', 'PK Livaha, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The end of WWII engendered the world’s most far-reaching experiment in international cooperation between sovereign nation states.  European countries embarked on a process of integration which has brought them peace, stability and prosperity. Yet, on the European Union’s 60th anniversary, celebrations are noticeably muted with citizens’ support for European integration flagging.  How come?

This course explores the historical, political, and economic background to European integration.  It will elucidate the EU’s unique origins, institutions and competences, and debate its place in the world and its relationship to member states.  The course sets out to provide the theoretical foundations to critically discuss questions on EU governance, key policy areas, crises and reforms, and to contemplate the EU’s future.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the origins and evolution of European integration;
• Assess the political and economic motives of member states to join the European Union;

• Explain the necessary conditions for the transition from constitutional right to international right, as stated by Immanuel Kant in Toward Perpetual Peace (1795), and use this to evaluate the feasibility of the idea of a politically integrated Europe;
• Analyze and reproduce the arguments of Hegel against Kant's idea of global/European perpetual peace;
• Evaluate theories on European integration;
• Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof;
• Understand the economics behind monetary integration and assess the recent crisis in the Eurozone and potential solutions;
• Apply concepts of sovereignty to the EU in keeping with the latter's political form;
• Examine the European Union’s relations with the outside world;
• Articulate an informed view about current debates on the EU.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81614,2018,European Law: Justice and Home Affairs,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Coman Kund', 'mr. AA Abdalla', 'TP Poot, LL.M']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81379,2018,European Private International Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['dr. EA Ontanu', 'dr. J Constantino Chagas Lessa']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The globalisation of trade has led to an increase of transnational relations and situations that can require the application of different sets of rules in a cross-border context. For instance, an English company concludes a sales contract with a French company; an agent settled in the Netherlands represents a United States-based company in several European countries; a German consumer buys goods from a Swiss company over the internet; a semi-finished product manufactured in Spain causes damages in further production chain in Poland.

International legal practice is increasingly confronted with questions of private international (including procedural) law. The substantial diversity of jurisdiction and procedure rules, and the lack of harmonisation may increase legal uncertainty and ineffective adjudication.

This course focuses on the general concepts of private international law and the application of private international law. Particular attention is given to private international law at European Union level and to related international conventions. Where relevant, attention will be paid to comparative aspects, for example common law jurisdiction vs. civil law jurisdiction.

The instruments to be discussed include those dealing with international jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, evidence, service of documents, harmonised European procedures (i.e. European Order for Payment, European Small Claims, European Account Preservation Order), insolvency, and the applicable law to (commercial) contracts and torts.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>A student who has successfully completed this course should:

column2: • identify the sources of private international law;
• assess the importance and problems of harmonisation of private international law at European level, and to some extent at international level;
• understand general concepts of international jurisdiction, including lis pendens and forum non conveniens, forum shopping, choice of forum, jurisdiction in personam, and jurisdiction in rem;
• understand the concepts of recognition and enforcement, including reciprocity, exequatur, free movement of judgments, and grounds of refusal;
• understand general concepts and principles of conflicts of laws, including party autonomy, connecting factors, public policy, and overriding mandatory rules;
• compare the process of service of documents under the European Service Regulation and the Hague Service Convention, and apply the European Service Regulation;
• compare the process of obtaining evidence under the European Evidence Regulation and the Hague Evidence Convention, and apply the European Evidence Regulation;
• assess the position of weaker parties in European Private International Law;
• have a basic understanding of the European uniform procedures;
• apply European jurisdiction rules to concrete civil and commercial matters;
• determine how a concrete judgment regarding civil and commercial matters given in a Member State can be recognised and enforced in another Member State;
• determine on the basis of European legislation in a concrete case which law applies to commercial or civil relationship or claim;
• describe the interplay between the UN Convention of International Sales of Goods and Rome I Regulation;

• understand the concept of centre of main interest (COMI), determine jurisdiction and the applicable law in insolvency proceedings, the recognition and enforcement of opening of insolvency proceedings;
• analyse the relationship between European Private International Law and third states.

column1:
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81500,2018,European Union Health Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter'],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80488,2018,European Union Law,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['A Sarris, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A solid basic understanding of European Union Law is necessary not only for lawyers or for those working in areas such as policy, lobbying, diplomatic services; but also for anyone who wants to understand how the European Union’s (EU) and its Member States’ legislative and judiciary competences co-exist and how we have organized our system of differentiated powers on various subject matters.

This course is an introduction to the institutional and legal structure of the EU. It aims at providing a theoretical basis and the understanding of the practical application thereof by way of lectures and case studies.

The course first provides insights to the historical evolution of the EU, its institutions, instruments of EU law and the legislative procedure. After looking into the foundational legal principles governing EU law and how EU’s competence is shaped, the course moves onto EU substantive law, which is covered in four sessions. The topics which are dealt with in this context are EU Single Market Law, Competition Law, EU Citizenship, Equal Treatment, Fundamental Rights, and Migration and Asylum Law.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
On completion of this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof,
• Understand the foundations of EU Single Market Law, EU Competition Law, EU Citizenship, principle of Equal Treatment and Human Rights within the EU, and EU Migration Law,
• Distinguish the legal issues embedded in news items, literature etc.
• Point to the legal and institutional ways of solving basic legal problems/cases

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81673,2018,European Union Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['mr. MK Shahid', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'prof.dr. R Repasi']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80460,2018,European Union Policy-Making,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M Haverland'],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79464,2018,Europees belastingrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['prof.dr. P Kavelaars', 'Y Vink']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.
Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Begrippenapparaat + interpretatiemethoden
• Beginselen van het Europees recht
• Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
• Staatssteun in het VwEU
• Formeelrechtelijke aspecten van het EU-recht
• Fiscale richtlijnen van de EU
• Wisselwerking tussen EU-recht en nationaal fiscaal recht

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het EU belastingrecht en in het bijzonder het beslisschema van het Hof van Justitie.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het EU belastingrecht nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te toetsen op hun aanvaardbaarheid.
• Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80498,2018,Europees bestuur en vergelijkende bestuurskunde,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. JFM Koppenjan'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De rol en positie van de Europese unie staan volop in de aandacht. Burgers, bedrijven en overheden hebben in tal van opzichten met Europees beleid te maken. Het functioneren van ons land en van ons openbaar bestuur wordt sterk door ons lidmaatschap van de Europese Unie beïnvloedt. Tegelijkertijd staat de positie van Europese Unie onder druk en is de toekomst van de ontwikkeling van de Europese Unie onzeker.

Juist in dit tijdsgewricht is kennis van de wordingsgeschiedenis en het functioneren van de Europese Unie van groot belang. Allereerst om de aard van de zich voordoende ontwikkelingen en hun implicaties te kunnen begrijpen. Maar ook omdat bestuurskundigen functioneren in een bestel waarin de EU alom aanwezig is. De Europese integratie heeft ertoe geleid dat het functioneren van het openbaar bestuur op lokale, regionale en nationale bestuurslagen sterk met ontwikkelingen op Europees niveau samenhangen. Daarbij komt dat de EU niet los van ontwikkelingen op andere bestuurlijke niveaus staat, maar dat deze niveaus deel uit maken van de Europese Unie en dat, gegeven het grensoverschrijdende karakter van veel problemen en taken, deze niet simpel meer op lokaal of nationaal niveau afgehandeld kunnen worden. Tegelijkertijd doen nationale, regionale en lokale verschillen ertoe en is de mate waarin Europa erin slaagt daarmee om te gaan in toenemende mate bepalend is voor het succes van en de steun voor de Europese Unie.

In deze module verkrijgen studenten kennis over de wordingsgeschiedenis, de organen en het functioneren van de Europese Unie. Daarbij wordt kaartkennis gecombineerd met verdieping door toepassing van bestuurskundige theoretische invalshoeken (o.a. over integratiemechanismen, multi-level governance en democratie-opvattingen). Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een vergelijkend perspectief. Studenten wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met vergelijking als onderzoeksmethode. Het object van vergelijking betreft de inhoud van beleid en de organisatie en het functioneren van beleidssectoren tussen verschillende Europese landen, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van de totstandkoming of uitvoering van Europees beleid. Studenten voeren in een groep een internationaal vergelijkend onderzoek uit en rapporteren daarover. Deelnemers aan de International Summerschool worden in staat gesteld in direct contact met ‘mid-carrieer’ studenten uit andere landen verschillen in de organisatie en het functioneren van het openbaar bestuur in andere Europose landen te ervaren en te onderzoeken. Daartoe stelt elk van hen een onderzoekplan op, resulterend in een individueel onderzoeksverslag.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • de politieke wordingsgeschiedenis van de Europese Unie weergeven en de onderliggende mechanismen uitleggen;
• de belangrijkste instituties van de Europese Unie en hun onderlinge verhouding beschrijven
• het proces van vorming en uitvoering Europees beleid weergeven en vanuit bestuurskundig optiek de sterktes en zwaktes daarvan aangeven
• een gefundeerd oordeel geven over het democratische gehalte van het de Europese Unie en over mogelijke verbetervoorstellen
• de huidige ontwikkelingen in historisch perspectief plaatsen en een beargumenteerd oordeel geven op de maatschappelijke en bestuurlijke implicaties daarvan.
• een weloverwogen keuze maken ten aanzien van de opzet en uitvoering van vergelijkend onderzoek tussen verschillende landen in Europees perspectief en een dergelijk onderzoek uitvoeren.
• reflecteren op verschillen en overeenkomsten in de organisatie en het functioneren van beleidssectoren in verschillende landen

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81395,2018,Europees en internationaal arbeidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EJA Franssen', 'mr. A Zwanenburg', 'mr. EM Kuipers - Schoonderwoerd', 'mr. MN Kuijer', 'mr.dr. E van Vliet', 'mr.drs. JR Vos', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Naast deze meer individuele vraagstukken wordt ook ingegaan op de rol en de rechten van de (Europese) sociale partners binnen de Europese sociale dialoog.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student kan de invloed en doorwerking van Europees en internationaal (sociaal verzekerings)recht in het Nederlandse arbeidsrecht toepassen op een concrete casus.
• De student kan beoordelen welke rechter in een internationaal arbeidsgeschil bevoegd is en welk recht van toepassing is.
• De student kan beoordelen wanneer sprake is van internationale detachering, wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn en welke beperkingen wel en niet kunnen worden opgelegd aan internationale dienstverleners.

• De student kan de wijze waarop Europese vrijheden doorwerken in een concrete casus beoordelen en identificeren hoe en waar zich spanningen voordoen tussen deze vrijheden en het (nationale) arbeidsrecht.
• De student kan de ontwikkelingen in de Europese en internationale context schetsen en vanuit die context ontwikkelingen beoordelen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90367,2018,Evaluation of Development Policy, Programmes and Projects",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. SI Bergh'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The demand for evaluation has become large. Governments, parliaments, corporations and citizens all want to know whether programs are effective, for whom and in terms of which objectives, as well as the reasons that explain success or failure. In international cooperation, the demand has been particularly intense: funders want to know the results of the funds donated or lent, and tax payers ask if the money is well used. Evaluation studies can throw a light on these questions. The main idea running through the course is that evaluation is not a technical process that can be applied in a standard way, but that its value and usefulness are strongly related to political choices and circumstances. The course will focus on evaluation as a practice leading to action, but grounded in reflection on ideas behind the practice and on theories supporting the choice of methodology in evaluation. The course will touch upon philosophy of science and value theory, the political dimensions of evaluation, and results-based management. The course will develop practical skills, mainly through the assignment consisting of writing the Terms of Reference for an evaluation based on project documents relating to a real case.  The course also includes study visits to a Dutch NGO, the Court of Audit, and/or the Inspection and Evaluation Unit of the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: At the end of the course students will have:

column5: a good understanding of the significance of evaluation for policy, programme and project analysis in governments and non-governmental organizations.
acquired skills for the application of this knowledge and insight, including an ability to design and manage evaluations of social development policy and programs.

column2: </body>

BA Demena', 'dr. M Faling', 'dr. N van Stapele', 'dr. SI Bergh', 'prof.dr. AS Bedi', 'prof.dr. L Pellegrini']",,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: ""nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution"". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course, you will have a basic knowledge of:

column5: the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification);
the concepts of fitness and adaptation;
the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change;
the origin of abiotic and cellular life;
micro- and macroevolution;
speciation and extinction;
population genetics;
palaeontology;
human evolution.

column2: </body>

As you can see in the overview that would amount to:
1. 15 ECTS minimum should be related to the program History (we also approve courses from programmes like: Political Science, International Relations, Journalism etcetera).
2. 15 ECTS maximum non-study related courses. These courses will replace your minor.
You are free to choose your courses, as long as:
- The partner university approves (for some courses you will need prerequisite knowledge and some courses are not open to exchange students)
- The course succeeds the first year of the BA
- The course is not part of the MA or PHD program
- The course is not too practical
Plus you can do a language course for 6 ECTS maximum.
3. In general, you can only take courses that have been approved by the Examination Board of the ESHCC.
The exchange program is open for bachelor students only. Plus, it is only possible to go abroad during the first semester (term 1 and 2) of the BA-3.
You will have to meet the following conditions:
1. Average grade of 6.5. We will check the grade point average up to term 1 of BA-2*
Please note: Some universities outside Europe require an average of 7 for the BA-1 and BA-2. If you don't meet this criteria, they will have the right to deny your application.
More information can be found on the pages of the partner universities.
2. At the time of registration (1 December 2018) students are required to:
a. Have completed all courses of BA-1*
b. Have completed all courses of BA-2, term 1**
*In case you have Personal Circumstances for the courses of BA-1
You are still allowed to register for the exchange program. If you fail to finish BA-1 in the second year, the International Office will have to withdraw your registration for the exchange program.
** In case you have a re-sit exam for a course Term 1 or 2 of the BA-2:

Then you can still register for the exchange program. But it means that other students who meet the criteria, will get priority. Consequently it can happen that you will not be selected for the partner university of your first choice. But we will do our best to select you for your 2nd, 3rd or 4th choice.

If you fail the re-sit examof a course of term 1 and 2 of BA-2 and you cannot compensate it with another course, you can still go on exchange. However, please keep in mind that you will have to do the courses you have failed all over again in your fourth year.

3. If you choose a partner university that does not offer (a sufficient number of) English taught courses, you are required to submit proof of their proficiency in the language of the foreign exchange institution (at B2 level or higher).
Application is no longer possible for the exchange period of  2018-2019.
The registration period for 2019-2020 starts from 1 October until 1 December 2018.
See the Canvas page (CC6000) for more information and application form.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79385,2018,Experimental Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. GD Granic', 'dr. JTR Stoop']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82273,2018,Experimental Methods in Business Research,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. QPC Andre'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is built on three pillars: Testing research ideas with clean and rigorous experimental designs, applying the statistical techniques necessary to analyse these designs, and writing a research report about it that conforms to journal standards. Topics include: causal inference, experimental designs (factorial designs, within- vs. between-subject designs, mixed designs), validity of designs (internal, external, statistical, construct), experimental caveats (demand characteristics, confounds, experimenter expectancy, checks, measurement order, control variables), applying statistics to experimental designs (e.g., simple effects, simple slopes, contrasts, outliers, statistical power, simple mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation), data visualization, and scientific integrity (researcher degrees of freedom, questionable research practices, transparency, p-hacking)

We will examine these topics from the perspective of an applied behavioural researcher (with examples from fields such as marketing, organizational behaviour, economics, and psychology). Our focus is thus very practical—to help you overcome any issues that might arise in designing and conducting your experiment, analysing your data, writing up your results, and getting your paper published. An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (Python or R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
As in previous years, we may be able to collect data in the Erasmus Behavioural Lab.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The goal of this course is to learn how to design, analyse and report field or laboratory experiments.</body>

The FAECTOR Excellence Programme is a programme designed for the highly motivated Econometrie/Econometrics/BSc2 students. The goal of the programme is to give Bachelor students (pre-Master, second year or higher) the opportunity to see different sides of an econometric theme. This programme is organised in cooperation with the Erasmus School of Economics. Last year's theme was Artificial Intelligence. This year's theme will be announced in November/December. During this programme you will attend several lectures within this theme. Besides your academic knowledge you get the opportunity to develop your writing skills by writing small papers and soft skills with workshops like a presentation and debating workshop. You will also meet several companies during the programme. Finally, If you finish this programme successfully, you will receive 4 extracurricular ECTS and a certificate signed by the dean of Erasmus School of Economics. The FAECTOR Excellence Programme of 2019 will start in January and ends in June. There will be a lecture, inhouse day or workshop once every week in block 3, 4 and 5 (excluding week 8 of each block). At the end of the Programme there will be a ceremony where you will present one of your written papers to show your fellow students and your family what you have done during this programme. Here you will also get your certificate.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80802,2018,Facility Logistics Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Netherlands is well known for its expertise in distribution operations. Many American and Asian multinational companies have established their European logistics centre in the Netherlands (about 55%, according to HIDC, 2001), and it is the home base of many logistics service providers and operations. The logistics sector has a big impact on the Dutch economy. Warehousing and distribution are core businesses for many large and smaller firms. While most other courses in the SCM master focus primarily on external logistics and strategic issues, this course focuses on intra logistics (or facility logistics): process design and execution; operations, particularly those within facilities. External and intra logistics are strongly related and, even stronger, interdependent. We will address such questions as: what is the impact of a company’s distribution structure on the intra logistics system, and vice versa? What storage systems should be used under which circumstances, what handling systems, what is the best layout, which information systems are appropriate, and what is the resulting performance? Besides matters of system choice, operational storage and order picking strategies are also discussed.
During the course, a number of case-based assignments will be carried out. You may have to present your solutions to the case customers.

The course addresses several skills. These include presentations, consultancy (you have to defend solutions to your peers), data-mining with a database tool, design (make good quality layout drawings), and analysis of company-internal operations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of the course is to:

column2: <li>
Develop insight and elementary design skills in material handling and facility (particularly warehouse and transhipment) operations management.
<li>
Develop analytical skills in regards to logistics operations. Tools will be provided to enable you to structure, analyse and master the issues at hand.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81506,2018,Familie(vermogens)recht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. JJM Grapperhaus', 'prof.mr. AJM Nuytinck']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het familie(vermogens)recht begeleidt de mens als het ware in juridisch opzicht van de wieg tot het graf (en eigenlijk ook, gelet op art. 1:2 BW, in de periode vóór de geboorte en, gelet op de betekenis van het erfrecht, over het graf heen, dus in de periode na het overlijden). Werkelijk iedereen krijgt gedurende zijn leven met dit zo belangrijke rechtsgebied te maken. Het spreekt iedereen aan. Tot het vakgebied behoren het familierecht in enge zin (personen- en familierecht) en het familievermogensrecht (huwelijksvermogensrecht en erfrecht). Vandaar de overkoepelende naam voor dit vak, waarin de drie deelgebieden tot uitdrukking komen: familie(vermogens)recht.

Het eerste deel van het vak, het familierecht in enge zin of personen- en familierecht, vindt men in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek en in belangrijke verdragen, zoals het EVRM en de daarbij behorende Protocollen (‘family life’/‘vie familiale’), het IVBPR en het IVRK. Het rechtsgebied omvat regelingen met betrekking tot de juridische aspecten van het persoonlijk leven, zoals bloed- en aanverwantschap, naam, woonplaats, burgerlijke stand, huwelijk, geregistreerd partnerschap, (echt)scheiding, afstamming (familierechtelijke betrekking), adoptie, gezag over en omgang met minderjarigen, curatele, meerderjarigenbewind, mentorschap, afwezigheid en vermissing.

Het tweede deel van het vak, het huwelijksvermogensrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, is in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek opgenomen. Het huwelijksvermogensrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van het huwelijk, waaronder begrepen rechten en verplichtingen van echtgenoten, de wettelijke gemeenschap van goederen en huwelijkse voorwaarden. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de echtscheiding, waaronder begrepen pensioenverevening, alimentatie en de verdeling van de ontbonden huwelijksgemeenschap of de afwikkeling van verrekenbedingen in huwelijkse voorwaarden. In dit verband moet onder ‘huwelijk’ tevens ‘geregistreerd partnerschap’ worden begrepen en onder ‘echtscheiding’ tevens ‘beëindiging van het geregistreerd partnerschap met wederzijds goedvinden of door middel van gerechtelijke ontbinding’. Bovendien komt de rechtspositie van samenwoners zonder huwelijk of geregistreerd partnerschap (informele relatie) aan de orde, zowel tijdens de periode van samenwoning als na verbreking van de samenleving (feitelijke scheiding). Men zou dan ook kunnen spreken over ‘relatievermogensrecht’ als overkoepelende term voor huwelijksvermogensrecht, partnerschapsvermogensrecht en samenlevingsvermogensrecht.

Het derde deel van het vak ten slotte, het erfrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, vindt men in Boek 4 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek. Het erfrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de overgang van het vermogen van de erflater op diens erfgenamen. Centraal staan het versterferfrecht of ab intestaat erfrecht, d.w.z. het erfrecht dat geldt als er geen uiterste wilsbeschikkingen zijn gemaakt, het testamentair erfrecht, in het bijzonder de legitieme portie, de zogenaamde andere wettelijke rechten en de verdeling van de nalatenschap.

Uitgangspunt bij de behandeling van de stof tijdens de hoorcolleges zal zijn dat de kennis, opgedaan in het eerste studiejaar (inleiding privaatrecht) en in het tweede studiejaar (verbintenissenrecht, alsmede goederen- en insolventierecht), dus globaal gezegd: de kennis van het algemene vermogensrecht, nog paraat aanwezig is. Is uw kennis wat weggezakt, fris een en ander dan vóór de aanvang van de hoorcolleges weer even op. Zie ook de hierboven vermelde toelatingseisen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Met dit vak wordt beoogd de student vertrouwd te maken met het huidige positieve familie(vermogens)recht en de rechtspraktijk in familie(vermogens)rechtelijke zaken, alsmede met de actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van wetgeving en rechtspraak. De bedoeling van dit vak is het verschaffen van kennis van en inzicht in het recht met betrekking tot de hieronder onder ‘Inhoud’ genoemde drie deelgebieden en de verschillende onderdelen daarvan. Wie met goed gevolg het vak afsluit, is in staat om casusposities die zijn gerelateerd aan het personen- en familierecht, het huwelijksvermogensrecht en het erfrecht, te analyseren, te interpreteren en op te lossen, waarbij de drie verschillende deelgebieden van het vak geïntegreerd aan de orde komen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80478,2018,"Feminist Philosophy: Bodies, Binaries & Beyond",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['A Lee - Groen, MA', 'dr. JF van Houdt']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces students to the field of feminist philosophy through key texts by some of the most prominent figures in the field, such as Simone de Beauvoir, Judith Butler, Rosie Braidotti, Elizabeth Grosz and Luce Irigaray. Through the analysis of these texts, we will engage with a genealogy of feminist philosophy and explore one of its most contested sites of debate: the body.

We will start by critically assessing mainstream canonical philosophy, which has relied on a hierarchically charged binary opposition between mind and body that also correlates with the opposition between masculinity and femininity.  The course will examine how such binary thinking relates to structural (gender) inequalities, and how this has elevated the theorizing of the body in critical feminist thought. By unpacking different feminist positions regarding the themes of embodiment and binaries, students will develop an understanding of key traditions within the field of feminist philosophy, including equality feminism, sexual difference theory, gender performativity, feminist phenomenology and feminist new materialisms.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of key texts within the field of feminist philosophy of the body.
• Have a basic understanding of key re-conceptualisations of the body within feminist philosophy.
• Have a basic understanding of key thinkers in feminist philosophy such as Lloyd, de Beauvoir, Irigaray, Haraway, Butler, Young and hooks.
• Be able to describe and explain the problematic relation between feminism, philosophy and the body.
• Be able to describe and explain how the rational subject has typically been constructed against the natural realm and what this entails.
• Be able to describe and explain what is at stake politically, ethically and epistemologically in rethinking the body in feminist theory.
• Have a basic understanding of feminist stakes in addressing, and sometimes going beyond, binary thinking.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85370,2018,Feminist Theories and Strategies for Development: Global and Local Perspectives,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. A Chhachhi', 'dr. D Zarkov', 'dr. NYT Shehada', 'dr. R Kurian', 'dr. S Heumann', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: This course focuses on feminist theorization of gendered institutions with specific attention to the multiple forms of collective and individual actions and interventions in the fields of economic exclusion, sexuality and culture, from an intersectional perspective.

The first block explores the knowledge embedded in institutions and institutional practices, focusing on the family, the state and market(s). It pays special attention to the inter-linkages between these three institutions and their gendered practices of ruling. We explore the ways in which local and global processes have affected these three institutions, and we interrogate economic exclusions, heteronormative relationships and cultural identities that are constitutive of these institutional practices.

The second block theorizes the collective and individual actions and strategies for change and social transformation. Focusing on concepts of subjectivity, agency and power, we look at social spaces for transformative actions and social relations through which the actions are shaped, and institutions changed. The emphasis is on the relations of power in the fields of economic exclusion, sexuality and culture, both as separate social domains and as mutually constitutive fields. The third block explores the possibilities for and effects of individual and group interventions in institutional practices, social structures and the micro-politics of everyday life.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: learn to recognize and apply feminist analysis of the state, the market and the family, taking into account the intersections of gender with other social relations of power;
gain basic knowledge of feminist conceptualization of economic exclusion, sexuality and culture, and their institutional and structural inter-relatedness;
gain critical understanding of the relationship between conceptualizing and strategizing, and institutional practice and social change.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80036,2018,Filosofen aan het werk,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Zoeken naar een baan stelt men beter niet uit tot na het schrijven van de thesis. Filosofen komen na hun opleiding terecht op zeer uiteenlopende plekken in de samenleving: in het onderwijs, in de journalistiek, in de uitgeverij, in de politiek, in het onderzoek, in het zakenleven, in de kunsten, in bestuurlijke functies, of als vrij gevestigd consulent. In deze cursus zal van januari tot en met april één keer per maand aandacht worden besteed aan telkens één beroepsperspectief door alumni van de Faculteit der Wijsbegeerte.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80038,2018,Filosofie & Literatuur: Franz Kafka,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. AW Prins'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Er is waarschijnlijk geen schrijver die een zo diepe indruk heeft gemaakt op de filosofie van de 20e (en waarschijnlijk ook de 21e) eeuw als Franz Kafka (1883-1924). Enkele namen kunnen hier volstaan: Lukacs, Adorno, Benjamin, Bataille, Blanchot, Canetti, Arendt, Kundera, Derrida, Steiner, Deleuze en Guattari. Wat is het in Kafka’s werk dat zoveel filosofen, met zulke uiteenlopende achtergronden, heeft gefascineerd? Is het de luciditeit waarmee Kafka een wereld zonder heil schetst, is het de paradox van de ‘vertrouwde bevreemding’ die zijn werk uitstraalt, is het de radicale onleefbaarheid van het bestaan waar wij in het dagelijks leven liefst aan voorbijgaan? In dit college wordt vanuit intensieve lectuur van enkele cruciale teksten (o.a. De gedaanteverwisseling, Het vonnis) onderzocht wat Kafka voor de hedendaagse filosofie heeft betekend en kan betekenen. Daarbij zal overigens ook Sontags litanie tegen de Kafka-interpreten in Against Interpretation worden betrokken.
Voor nu, enkele fragmenten om ‘in de stemming’ te geraken:
“Er is oneindig veel hoop in deze wereld. Alleen niet voor ons.”
“Er is een doel, maar geen weg. Wat wij weg noemen is aarzeling.”
“Ik wankel echter daarboven, er is helaas geen dood, maar de eeuwige kwelling van het sterven.”

Bedenk hierbij wat Kafka kenner Verhaar schrijft: “Alleen voor degene die een hogere zin in het leven ziet is Kafka absurd pessimistisch. Wanneer je de mens voor redeloos, ontluisterend en inhumaan houdt is Kafka een verdediger van de mens.""

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1. Inzicht verkrijgen in de verhouding tussen filosofie en literatuur.
2. Het verwerven van diepgaand inzicht in de wijze waarop Kafka de absurditeit en ongerijmdheid van het bestaan articuleert.
3. Het vermogen zich zelfstandig tot de collegestof te verhouden.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81823,2018,Filosofie en Retorica,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. HA Krop', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In het theoretisch gedeelte van dit practicum staat de relatie tussen filosofie en retorica centraal. Hoewel de retorica in sommige tijden een vast onderdeel vormde van het wijsgerig curriculum, bestaat er al sinds Plato ook een spanning tussen retorica en filosofie en is vaak getracht de retoriek uit de wijsbegeerte te verbannen en de banden tussen ethos, logos en pathos te verbreken. Ook zullen docenten van binnen en buiten de faculteit hun eigen visie verdedigen op de relatie tussen filosofie en retorica en de rol van retorica in politiek, maatschappij en wetenschap.

In het praktisch gedeelte van het practicum Filosofie en retorica zal de theorie en geschiedenis van de retorica worden besproken en klassieke en meer recente teksten over retorica gepresenteerd. Daarnaast wordt meer praktisch geoefend in spreek- en discussievaardigheden. Zo zullen studenten in enkele intensieve workshops worden getraind in het herkennen en beoefenen van retorische stijlmiddelen en zullen docenten hun eigen retorische expertise bespreken en in praktijk brengen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Aan het eind van de cursus heeft de student zowel historisch en theoretisch inzicht in de relatie van de retorica tot de filosofie ontwikkeld, als praktische vaardigheid verworven om over wijsgerige onderwerpen in het openbaar te spreken en het eigen standpunt toe te lichten.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79133,2018,Filosofie van de economie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. JJ Vromen'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het doel van de cursus is om studenten vertrouwd te maken met elementaire concepten en ideeën uit de filosofie die relevant zijn voor economie. Meer in het bijzonder worden kwesties uit de methodologie van de economie, zoals de vragen hoe onrealistisch economische modellen mogen en moeten zijn en hoe we kunnen beoordelen hoe groot hun verklarende kracht is, en kwesties uit de ethiek van de economie, zoals de vraag naar ongelijkheid, verdelende rechtvaardigheid en morele grenzen van de markt, geïntroduceerd en toegelicht. In drie werkgroepen worden ethische vraagstukken in het bedrijfsleven op drie verschillende niveaus aan de orde worden gesteld: op het niveau van de markt, van de onderneming en van stakeholders. Door actief met de materie bezig te zijn ontwikkelen studenten een sterker moreel besef en maken zij zich denkkaders eigen om tot een meer doordachte en evenwichtige eigen oordeelsvorming te komen.</body>

<body>

Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de methodologie van de economie.
Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de vakgebieden waar economie en ethiek elkaar overlappen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81814,2018,Filosofisch Atelier,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle', 'dr. PJJ Delaere', 'prof.dr. FA Muller', 'prof.dr. HA Krop']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Dit practicum, waarin academische vaardigheden worden geoefend, bestaat uit een onderdeel ‘introductie’ en een onderdeel ‘filosofie en film’.

Deel 1 (blok 1A): De introductiebijeenkomsten beogen de eerstejaars studenten in te leiden en in te wijden in een academische beoefening van de filosofie. Al op de eerste bijeenkomst zal worden gezocht naar een goede balans tussen de eigen verwachtingen en de eisen die de studie stelt. Ook zal aandacht worden besteed aan motivatie, attitude en het structureren van de zelfstudie (voorbereiding op colleges en toetsen). Er zijn bijeenkomsten voorzien over ‘de ethiek van het lezen’, waarin verschillende genres teksten worden besproken en de daarbij passende houding van de lezer. Er worden bijeenkomsten gewijd aan het volgen van hoorcollege; het gebruik van de ub; citeren, verwijzen en frauderen; en het schrijven van een samenvatting,. Bij dit deel van het practicum zijn ook de studieadviseur en enkele ouderejaars studenten van de faculteit betrokken.

Deel 2 (blok 2A): In het ‘filosofie en film’-gedeelte staan een aantal filosofische thema’s in het werk van Michelangelo Antonioni centraal. Verschillende docenten verzorgen colleges over de thema’s en gekozen films. Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij essays schrijven, elkaars essays beoordelen, presenteren en debatteren over de films en de thema’s. De nadere invulling van het practicum wordt via Canvas bekend gemaakt.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Het Filosofisch Atelier is verplicht voor voltijdstudenten en wordt niet aangeboden aan deeltijdstudenten. Deeltijdstudenten nemen deel aan de cursus 'Schrijven' (FW-VAA1008).
Inzicht krijgen in de academische beoefening van filosofie en het vermogen ontwikkelen om in korte opdrachten de filosofische thema’s en importantie van verschillende films onder woorden te brengen.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80172,2018,FinTech,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. T Lambert'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

FinTech covers technology-enabled business model innovation in the financial services industry. FinTech is rapidly evolving across the globe and represents an existential challenge for major parts of the financial sector. These innovative technologies can disrupt existing industry structures and blur industry boundaries, facilitate disintermediation, radically change how firms create and deliver products and services, generate significant privacy, regulatory and law-enforcement challenges, offer new gateways for entrepreneurship, and create opportunities for inclusive growth.

In this course, we will provide an introductory overview of innovations that are central to FinTech. Specifically, these innovations include cryptocurrencies and the blockchain, mobile and digital payment systems, social trading and robo advice, marketplace lending, crowdfunding. We will also explore threats and opportunities that these technologies pose to incumbent firms and discuss the way that FinTech interacts with law enforcement and regulation issues. The approach adopted to address these themes is analytical. Furthermore, the course will feature a number of guest speakers from industry.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Demonstrate a broad understanding of what FinTech is and why it emerged.
• Understand and explain the fundamentals of the following FinTech: blockchain/cryptocurrency, payment systems, crowdfunding, marketplace lending, social trading/robo advice.
• Analyze the potential of these FinTech and evaluate why they may change financial services.
• Understand and explain how technology and regulation are interacting and impacting on financial services.
• Critically assess new technologies and FinTech business models.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80620,2018,Financial Accounting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Koning', 'prof.dr. EM Roelofsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Accounting information is vital for the functioning of our economies: investors use accounting information to value stocks, loan officers use accounting information when deciding on whether or not to lend money to a business and managers use accounting information to communicate to outside parties the extent to which they were successful in running the business. Financial statements are the principal means of communicating accounting information about a business to outsiders. The objective of this course is not to train you to become accountants but to help you become critical users of financial statements. The achievement of this goal requires an understanding of the concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements and an appreciation of the amount of judgment required in applying accounting concepts. Topics include: the institutional setting and fundamental concepts and techniques underlying financial statements, the accounting treatment of various financial statement items (e.g., inventory, PPE, intangible assets, investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity) and the analysis of financial statements.

This course continues from the foundations established in the introductory course in Foundations of Finance & Accounting and goes on to explore the theory, concepts and procedures underlying external financial statements and reports for corporate organizations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of the course, the student should be able to:

column2: <li>
Understand the fundamental principles, concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements
<li>
Understand, use and analyze the main items on a company’s financial statements
<li>
Understand and use the relationships between financial statements
<li>

Understand accounting treatments described by accounting rules and apply these accounting treatments to financial statement items (e.g., inventory, PPE, intangible assets, investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity)
<li>
Evaluate the impact of different accounting treatments on financial statements
<li>
Calculate and interpret financial ratios
<li>
Forecast financial statements and evaluate the assumptions behind forecasted financial statements

column1: At the end of this course the student should have obtained the following skills:

column2: • Analytical thinking;
• Problem identification/solving;
• Reading scientific articles;
• ​Business ethics.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80711,2018,Financial Analysis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['drs. HT Haanappel'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course takes the user perspective of financial statements (investment analyst, portfolio manager, and business analyst) as the user interprets financial reports, analyses operating and financial performance and prepares forecasts. Key is interpreting the financial statements in general and specific line items in specific to assess and forecast key value drivers such as quality of earnings, working capital, capex, taxes and cash flows. In addition the returns from a firm and equity perspective will be analyzed. Furthermore in this course we will also review the credit perspective on financial analysis. The course will focus on listed companies in a financial market setting and takes a practical perspective as annual reports of listed companies will studied and guest lectures will present their results.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • To become acquainted with financial reporting requirements and practices
applied by global firms

financial statements

<body>It is a data-driven world with an extreme competition for analytical talent, according to research by McKinsey Global Institute and McKinsey Analytics in 2017. In this course, I will discuss two main techniques to deal with structured data and unstructured data at entry level: 1) textual analysis and 2) machine learning. It aims to introduce a set of analytical tools for understanding and examining real-time data examples in R. Students need to complete empirical assignments in R to enhance the knowledge and skills learned in the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After having followed this course, students should:

column2: • Understand structured and unstructured data.
• Apply textual analysis to work with R on unstructured data.
• Apply machine learning techniques to work with R on structured data.
• Analyze real-life cases with analytic thinking.
