https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81185,2018,"Globalisation and the Making of Europe, 1850-present",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JJ Euwe'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the  world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains,  and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can explain the history and theory of international economic relations since the 19th century
• Students can explain how developments in Europe’s political economy since the 19th century are related to globalization
• Students are able to assess Europe’s political-economical position in the world

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81080,2018,Globalisation, culture and place",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AMC Brandellero'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place; the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.  This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales; and how trends and social conventions spread across the world; and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80370,2018,Globalisation: Historical Perspectives from the Global South,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['B Hesseling, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The interplay between ‘East’ and ‘West’ is under plenty of scrutiny in both political discourse and media. In the popular imagination, especially in Western societies, there seems to be an increasingly common idea of ‘East’ and ‘West’ being monolithic entities that differ fundamentally from each other. Historians and other scientists have also been increasingly occupied by this topic as the many publications in the past few decades illustrate.

The aim of this course is to link up critically with the paradigm of ‘East’ and ‘West’ or, according to some, ‘East’ vs. ‘West’. We will compare Eastern and Western societies with each other and we shall trace globalisation from Antiquity to present day. For the ancient Greek historian Herodotus, ‘Europe’ was the domain of ‘uncivilised barbarians’. This begs the question when ‘Europe’ was constructed as a cultural entity and heir of ancient Greek civilisation. Was there ever a harmonious relationship between East and West? Was there intensive contact and cultural exchange? For example, the Crusades may suggest battle and separation. On the other hand war and conflict have brought about intensive cultural, political and economic ties.

A historical methodology will permeate throughout this course. Our weekly discussions will not only be based on secondary sources, but also on primary sources. We will pay particular attention to the interplay between political economy and Globalisation in its broadest sense- meaning exchange of culture, religion, conflict and so on. Understanding present day global currents requires an in-depth knowledge of historical exchanges that have shaped them. Transatlantic Slavery, Eastern Enlightenment and the ‘Arab Spring’ are some of the issues we will tackle in order to gain an understanding of Globalisation from a critical perspective.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Problematize ‘Europe’ as a cultural construct.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Edward Said’s critique of orientalism.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column1:
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86520,2018,Globalization and Global Governance,Nederlands,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,[],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81302,2018,Globalization and Media Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AFM Krijnen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming, satellite dishes, digital technology) and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural-industry business.

Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalization.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalization processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81401,2018,Globalization and Multidimensional Legal Orders,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. F Violi', 'dr. M van der Sluis', 'prof.dr. KAM Henrard, LLM']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81333,2018,"Globalization, Digitalization and Culture",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. P Arora'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders. Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production.  This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • normative constructs in new media studies and dominant perspectives on digital cultures
• the development of key concepts on the globalization of the internet and persistent discourses on the digital divide
• the intellectual history and theoretical shifts in the framing of culture, community and technology
• apply relevant theoretical insights and methods to their topic of choice
• critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form
• design and write an essay; make an intellectually compelling argument on globalization of the internet and its relationship to culture
• create a short video pitch on their argument to speak to the lay person on their cause

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81676,2018,Goederen- en Insolventierecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. P Tchai', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het goederenrecht vormt samen met het verbintenissenrecht een van de twee pijlers van het vermogensrecht. Iedereen heeft te maken met goederenrecht, of het nu de vraag betreft wie eigendom van een gestolen fiets heeft of de vraag aan welke eisen een bank moet voldoen wil zij bewerkstelligen dat zij een geldig pandrecht krijgt op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur. Het goederenrecht is daarnaast onlosmakelijk verbonden met het insolventierecht. Denk aan vragen als, moet de curator van de dief van bovengenoemde gestolen fiets deze fiets ook in faillissement teruggeven, of moet de fiets juist ten behoeve van de gezamenlijke schuldeisers worden verkocht? En mag de bank, die een geldig pandrecht op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur heeft verkregen, haar vordering in faillissement verrekenen? Dat en meer komt aan bod tijdens het vak goederen- en insolventierecht.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In dit vak komt zowel het goederenrecht als het insolventierecht aan de orde. Bij het B1-vak Inleiding privaatrecht is de basis van het goederenrecht in hoofdlijnen behandeld. In dit vak wordt dieper op het goederenrecht ingegaan en staan verhaal, zekerheid en insolventie centraal. Het vak heeft daarbij tot doel de studenten de hoofdregels van het goederen- en insolventierecht bij te brengen, zodat zij in de (commerciële) praktijk zelfstandig een goederen- of insolventierechtelijke casus kunnen oplossen. Vanwege het grote belang van dit leerstuk in de praktijk wordt extra diep ingegaan op het leerstuk van de verpanding van vorderingen.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course is open to all Master students, PhD candidates and faculty members. It is assumed that participants have some basic knowledge on how to interpret analyses. For teaching and practice purposes, participants will use simulated datasets.

Discuss what meta-analysis is and how it has been applied in management and economics over the years. We will focus on the three general goals (determine overall size of an effect, moderator analyses, mediation analyses) and discuss steps 1 and 2 above.
Discuss extensively steps 3 and 4 and do some short exercises on how to develop a questionnaire and start coding of studies.

Discuss step 5 and do analyses together in a computer lab. If there is time, Marc will also focus on some of his new work and new possibilities in meta-analyses. In the afternoon there is time for some individual appointments.

We expect this to be an interactive class. We expect that everyone is an active and motivated participant, is prepared to ask questions, discuss alternative views, and contribute to the flow of the class. For further information please contact Marc van Essen (marc.vanessen@moore.sc.edu)</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course is open to all PhD candidates, RM students and faculty members. However, we assume that participants have some basic knowledge of regression analysis and can interpret its results.

The course aims to teach participants how to develop coding questionnaires and code studies. It also shows how to perform data analysis, draw conclusions, and present findings, thus giving some indications on how to get published in a top journal. Moreover, we theoretically discuss and empirically show the benefits and limitations of meta-analysis.
We go through the following steps of meta-analytical research:

column2: • Selection of topic and research proposition;
• Collection of studies;
• Development of coding questionnaires;
• Coding of studies;
• Analysis of the data, drawing conclusions, and presentation of findings;

column1: We will also provide explanations on how to get your work published in a journal.

<body>

column3: In the governance lab students will be confronted  with real life governance problems and will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge of the courses in analyzing these problems but also be challenged to develop practical solutions for the problems they are working on. Practitioners presenting the governance problems to students will provide feedback on the given solutions. As such the governance lab sessions will provide the practical testing ground for developing analytical and managerial skills of the students.

column2: </body>

<body>

column3: After the governance lab sessions students are able to:
• recognize and analyze practical governance problems;
column5: assist practitioners with their analysis of governance problems and develop practical solutions for these problems;

column3:
• organize processes of joint decision-making and problem solving;
  • reflect on the problems they analyse and the solutions they porovide as well as on the processes that take place to organize these.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This module introduces the students to ‘law and governance’ by focusing on a field that combines both perspectives: regulatory governance. ‘Regulation’, which is not necessarily a synonym for ‘rulemaking’, is central to governing society. The regulatory approach to law and governance recognizes that law cannot solve all societal problems but also that law brings important safeguards to the table. The governance perspective points to the importance of solid institutional design and culture. Why do we regulate and what do we know about different regulatory approaches, including self-regulation? In what ways do international organisations and NGOs try to influence domestic regulatory governance? The course also deals with the possibilities and limitations of regulatory impact analysis and participation as central governance tools.

The module takes a practical approach, using group work on case studies as a way of gaining experience with the application of tools and concepts of regulatory governance in the context of public administration and law making.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of this module the students will have:

column5: Understood the basic tools and concepts of governance and regulatory governance in particular.
Thought about how to apply these in the practical context of public administration and lawmaking.
Appreciated the roles and functions of different governance tools, such as indicators in international and national lawmaking processes.
Considered various regulatory governance strategies and have acquired experience with choosing a strategy in a particular situation.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82218,2018,Governance and Strategy,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. J Weenink', 'J Kostenzer', 'MJ Stevens, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
• Students are able to explain theories on governance and strategy.
• Students are able to analyse governance issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on governance.
• Students are able to analyse strategic issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on strategy.
• Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges and changes in healthcare governance and strategy;
• Students are able to deal with, and reflect on, complex healthcare issues in a serious game.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81883,2018,Governance of Migration and Diversity,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Pisarevskaya', 'dr. AS Leerkes', 'dr. FG Snel', 'dr. M Schiller', 'dr. M van Houte, MSc', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course provides a broader theoretical background on issues of governance in migration and diversity, integrating the various disciplinary perspectives of the GMD master programme (history, sociology, public administration, urban studies, international relations and development) and connects these to topical and hands-on governance questions of migration and diversity.

The course consists of preparatory sessions focusing on the theoretical background of the respective governance issues and site-visits to organizations involved in the topic. The subject for the seminars and site-visits vary depending on what is topical at the time, but can include topics like discrimination, radicalisation, segregation, high-skilled migration, refugee migration, migration corridors, transnational communities and political representations of migrants. During the seminars and site-visits the students engage in discussion with both scholars and practitioners on the topic.
Finally the students will apply their interdisciplinary knowledge on governance of migration and diversity in a critical review of governance issue of choice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Understand how theoretical perspectives of the master programme can be integrated and applied around topical issues of migration and diversity governance
• Apply the literature from the master programme to concrete governance challenges in migration and diversity
• Critically assess a governance issue from different disciplinary perspectives

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86514,2018,Governance, State and Society",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. SMS Jayasundara - Smits'],,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The course examines the nature, legitimacy and capacity of the state by reviewing relevant concepts and theory, and considers the degree of institutionalisation of states and state agencies along a continuum of strong states to ‘failed states’ and from autocratic to democratic regimes. Attention is given to the executive, legislative and judicial functions of states. Internal structures of governments are considered in relation to policy-making processes, state and organisational capacity and the involvement of state and non-state actors and organisations at national and local levels.

Specific attention is given to the people: the heterogeneous subjects of states, the voters and policy target groups, and to their formal and informal (patronage) relationships with state and political actors. The focus is on actual realities of state-society relations and the dynamics of change, including efforts by governments and donor agencies to improve governance and state-society relationships, for example by enhancing accountability and reducing corruption. Throughout the course there is attention for the position and representation of vulnerable groups such as women and the poor.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Upon completion of the course, students will be familiar with fundamental concepts and theoretical approaches on 1) the multi-actor nature of contemporary governance; 2) power and politics; 3) the nature, legitimacy and capacity of the state; 4) the nature of the policy process and policy-making, and 5) the relations between governments, citizens, and civil society.  They will also have acquired competencies in the analysis of the role of the state in relation to markets and the economy as well as how states are affected by globalization and policies of International Financial Institutions. Through the course work, students will learn to apply this knowledge to concrete case studies and communicate findings effectively.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80441,2018,Governing Healthy Cities,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. G Noordzij'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In this course we concern ourselves with the ways in which health and healthcare have come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policy-making and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The traditional image of policy as a linear process from policy conception, via implementation to evaluation has thereby been left behind. In this course, we discuss different models that have been advanced to come to grips with this increased uncertainty and complexity in policymaking, both in terms of understanding and analysing policy processes and in the process of governing health and healthcare itself.

Apart from theoretical input, the course will use two cases to explore several key governance processes: integrated care and prevention, and eHealth (but these may be subject to change). We discuss the position of key actors (e.g. professionals, patients, regulators), underlying governance mechanisms (e.g. the New Public Management, self-management and ‘positive health’) and the effects of specific policy instruments. We use a comparative perspective looking at experiences in different countries and across different fields of healthcare (e.g. hospital care, long-term care and mental healthcare). During the course the students work on an essay on a current issue in healthcare governance. Apart from the essay grading will be based on an open-questions exam.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is for students to get acquainted with healthcare governance as a concept and the different shapes and forms of governance in practice. More specifically, the following learning goals apply to this course:

column2: • Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82185,2018,Governing Healthy Cities,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['DV Ivanova, PhD', 'S Huizenga - Rahmawan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health.  In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions needs to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge about governance of healthy cities as well as skills to perform ‘action research’ in the city of Rotterdam on the basis of which they will write a policy report. By following this course, students will develop an in-depth understanding of the possibilities and difficulties of governing healthy cities.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/77528,2018,Groei en ontwikkeling van het kind,Nederlands,Erasmus MC Academie,,[],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81607,2018,Grondslagen van de criminologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. JVAG Piret', 'drs. M Kleijn', 'K Oosterwijk, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Handelingen en gedragingen als misdaad kwalificeren en bestraffen, is geen theorieloze en eeuwig onveranderlijke praktijk. Aan dit gebeuren liggen talrijke filosofische en politieke vooronderstellingen ten grondslag die evolueren in de tijd. Over deze theoretische vooronderstellingen en achterliggende historische denkkaders, wordt in het vak grondslagen van de criminologie gereflecteerd.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Inzicht verschaffen in de maatschappelijke verhoudingen en filosofische opvattingen die een rol hebben gespeeld bij de historische ontwikkeling van de ideeën over misdaad en straf.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de vraag waarom in bepaalde historische periodes gewetensdelicten zoals ketterij strafwaardig geacht werden en hoe men reageerde op een verdenking van hekserij.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol die de godsdienst speelde in de vervolging van gewetensdelicten en hekserij.

• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag waarom een staat het recht heeft om diegenen die afwijken van bepaalde normen te straffen en inzicht verschaffen in de wijze waarop dit filosofisch gerechtvaardigd wordt?
• Studenten kritisch leren reflecteren over de reikwijdte van overheidsmacht en over de filosofische oorsprong en de grondslag van individuele rechten tegenover de staat.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol en de betekenis van de Verlichtingsfilosofie in dit proces.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat tussen utilisten en retributivisten in de strafrechtsfilosofie.
• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag of (en zo ja hoe) foltering en de doodstraf kunnen gerechtvaardigd worden (en indien niet, waarom?)
• Inzicht verschaffen in de verschillende ethische theorieën die een antwoord formuleren op de vraag wanneer de overheid iets strafrechtelijk mag verbieden?
• Studenten kritisch doen nadenken over de vraag of alleen individuen misdaden kunnen plegen dan wel of ook staten en (internationale) organisaties dat doen?
• Studenten doen reflecteren over de vraag of het object van de criminologie ruimer is dan louter datgene wat door de strafwetgever strafbaar is gesteld.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met de manier waarop de criminologie als wetenschap is ontstaan en hoe zij zich verhoudt tot de (totalitaire) politiek.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat over vrije wil en determinisme in de strafrechtstheorie.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78799,2018,Groups at Work,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. H van Mierlo'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

It is no coincidence that our psychology curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement with groups will be about improving them, about suggesting or implementing changes to make groups or teams more effective. In your future job you may, for example, train groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, design groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By presenting state-of-the-art knowledge about various aspects of groups at work, this course will give you the opportunity to prepare for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of group work.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>‘Groups at Work’ is a specialized Master course that will introduce you to different aspects of groups at work. The tutorial group meetings and lectures enable you to become familiar with the state of affairs in group research and encourage you to further develop an academic attitude: a constructive, critical attitude towards the things you see, hear, and read. At the end of this course:

column2: • You have knowledge and understanding of the basics of groups at work, diversity in groups, group processes and emergent states, and group leadership.
• You have developed a critical view of the literature about these topics

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85354,2018,Growth, Inequality and Poverty",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,"['prof.dr. L Pellegrini', 'prof.dr. RE van der Hoeven', 'prof.dr. SM Murshed']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: This course will address matters related to long-term economic growth, as well as related issues in inequality (the distribution of income and wealth) and poverty that ultimately contribute to sustainable development. One of the major problems associated with development are the low-incomes of today’s developing countries. For most poor countries growth constitutes the principal avenue via which poverty can be reduced, as growth provides greater opportunities and enlarges the economic pie. Another, related, issue concerns distributive justice, both at the national level and between nation states. Excessive inequality can undermine societal cohesion and human security. Today’s rich countries are affluent because they historically grew faster than the poor nations of the world. The study of the causes of rapid growth is, therefore, important. What is the difference between growth trickling down to the indigent and destitute, and genuinely pro-poor growth. We are constantly being told that increased international trade and openness is key to economic success. But, does trade benefit all countries equally? Is trade between the North and the South less advantageous for the South? Also, trade is meant to be an engine of growth, but has growing trade in our globalized era brought average incomes in the world closer together or further apart?   In addition to the theory and empirical evidence connected with the issues enumerated above, students will become familiar with the analytical tools required to apply these and other issues towards more detailed case studies, and comparative analyses.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students will have a clear understanding of 1) the long-term patterns of growth; 2) new theories regarding the determinants of growth, international trade and trade policy; 3) the link between economic growth and poverty, as well as the interaction between growth and inequality; 4) the importance of growing inter-national inequality;  5) the long-term causes of growth which include the links between economic growth, natural resource endowments, culture, geography, democracy and institutions, as well as how these linkages are influenced by economic policies; 6) put their own country experience with economic reform policies in a comparative perspective; and, 7) undertake empirical analysis to assess the impact of institutions and other economic reform policies on long-term economic growth and poverty reduction.

column2: </body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84629,2018,HP: Communicating Sustainability in an Intercultural Context,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AR Vasques', 'dr. MCM Sommier', 'dr. Y Wang']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

HONOURS PROGRAMME - What is sustainability? Why should it matter to you? Answering these questions will generate more questions. In this course, the concept of sustainability will be presented and discussed from several perspectives.  Students will gain insights into the triple bottom line approach to sustainability and examine the different aspects and challenges it encompasses for contemporary societies and individuals. This approach allows students to explore three aspects of sustainability: social, environmental and economic dimensions.

Throughout this course, students will not only acquire both a theoretical and practical understanding of sustainability, but also develop a variety of skills to conduct empirical research on this topic. Students will have the opportunity to collaborate with participants from China to collect first-hand data. Students’ own research projects will allow them to investigate sustainability practices in China. This course is designed for students to engage with the intercultural dimension of sustainability and work in small diverse groups on their research project.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After the course, students have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • the triple bottom line approach to sustainability;
• sustainability as a multilayered concept that has implications for individuals and societies;
• the relation between sustainability and intercultural aspects;

column1: After the course, students are able to:

column2: • evaluate sustainable-related issues in practice through both qualitative and quantitative approaches;
• promote creative solutions for a balanced model of sustainability (environmental, social and economic);
• collaborate with international partners and work efficiently in intercultural settings

column1: After this course, students will be awarded with:

column2: • 5 ECTS
• a certificate for this honors program
• an experience of recording a professional video at the Community for Learning Innovation (CLI) lab.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80132,2018,"HRM, Leiderschap en performance",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De module biedt een inleiding in de centrale theorieën in de wetenschappelijke literatuur over Human Resource Management (HRM), leiderschap en prestaties. Conform de ontwikkeling van dit vakgebied, waarbij vooral de strategische betekenis van de personele factor wordt benadrukt, wordt ook aandacht geschonken aan de context waarin HRM tot stand komt, waarbij met name ontwikkelingen op de arbeidsmarkt zullen worden besproken. Aangezien HRM niet losgezien kan worden van leiderschap zal ook worden ingegaan op de wijze waarop leiderschapsstijl de relatie tussen HRM en prestaties beïnvloedt.

De module bouwt voort op organisatie en management uit de B1. Daarnaast wordt voortgebouwd op de M&T leerlijn in het curriculum, waarbij vooral wordt ingegaan op het ontwerp van (kwantitatief en kwalitatief) onderzoek en de bijbehorende analyses. In de werkgroepen worden de aangereikte theorieën en modellen toegepast en onderzoeksvaardigheden verder uitgebouwd.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • De centrale wetenschappelijke concepten en theorieën in het vakgebied van Human Resource Management (HRM), performance en leiderschap uitleggen.
• Beredeneren welke verschillen er op het terrein van HRM, performance en leiderschap tussen organisaties in de publieke en private sector bestaan.
• Het strategisch HRM-beleid van een organisatie analyseren en daarover rapporteren.
• Leiderschapsstijlen herkennen in zelf verzamelend empirische data
• Op basis van dit materiaal verbanden weergeven en interpreteren tussen leiderschap en motivatie

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Hoe komt de koffie van Brazilië in uw kopje? Het stromen van de koffie is niet of nauwelijks geregeld via wetgeving of verdragen. De regulering vindt voornamelijk plaats via het contractenrecht. Honderden contracten zijn nodig om de koffie te laten stromen en al die contracten moeten doelgericht samenhangen. Handelsverkeersrecht heeft dan ook een eigen problematiek en dat is de problematiek van het contractuele web. Het burgerlijk recht lijkt gemaakt voor twee partijen-situaties en het handelsrecht kan daar soms moeilijk mee overweg omdat het in het handelsverkeersrecht gaat om een onderneming: het verplaatsen van goederen, waarbij veel partijen betrokken zijn. Die partijen zijn allemaal geschakeld in afzonderlijke twee-partijenovereenkomsten, die samen op een bepaalde manier een geheel moeten vormen. De afzender sluit een vervoerovereenkomst met een vervoerder, maar dit vervoer is van meet af aan op aflevering aan een ontvanger gericht. Die ontvanger is de werkelijke belanghebbende bij een behouden aankomst. In geval van beschadiging van de goederen zal het de ontvanger zijn die schade lijdt en deze schade vergoed wil zien. De ontvanger is alleen geen wederpartij van de vervoerder. Hoe moet dat nu? In de loop der eeuwen heeft het recht instrumenten ontwikkeld om een goede weg te vinden in een web van overeenkomsten. Waardepapieren spelen daarbij een belangrijke rol, maar ook bijvoorbeeld de figuur van de verzekering heeft daarbij een niet weg te denken taak.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Na dit vak kent, begrijpt en kan de student toepassen:
het weven van de belangrijkste draden van het web van contracten dat in de praktijk gevormd wordt om de internationale stroom van goederen juridisch in goede banen te leiden.

Het gaat daarbij met name om de essentialia van de koop, waardepapieren, bancaire diensten, vervoer, verzekering en vertegenwoordiging en de juridische relaties die deze contracten met elkaar hebben, waarbij de leerstukken vertegenwoordiging, derdenbeding, onrechtmatige daad, eigendom, pand en waardepapieren ervoor zorgen dat derden bij een contract betrokken kunnen worden.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79983,2018,Harnessing creativity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Deichmann', 'prof.dr. DA Stam', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80936,2018,Health Care Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. MMH Strating'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Health is of great value to humans, and access to affordable health services of high quality is a human right. The degree to which various health service providers organisations succeed to deliver varies considerably. In part this variation can be attributed to national policies and other factors which are external to the organisations. In this minor we focus however on the characteristics of organisations which influence their performance, and specifically the quality of the health services they offer.

To this purpose the minor consists of three parts of three weeks. The first part addresses how to assess the performance of health service provider organisations, and the influence of management on performance. The second part addresses performance improvement and innovation. We study and apply improvement methods for improving efficiency, quality and safety. In addition we analyse how cultures and human behaviours impact performance.  The final part of the minor addresses the role of  technology, communication, and cooperation with other organisations and the customers. We discuss how state of the art co-creation among multiple organisations, and between providers and patients advance quality of service and health benefits.

column2: • Students can define appropriate performance measures for health service provider organisations across the globe, and benchmark performance between organisations
• Students understand the potential impact of management on improving health service performance, and the limitations
• Students can design, manage and improve health service processes using state of the art techniques such as Six Sigma.
• Students can analyse cultural characteristics of organisations and relate it to performance, improvement & innovation
• Students can place technological innovations in a societal context and identify the resulting value improvements and entrepreneurial opportunities

• Students can place the performance of a health service provider organisation in the context of a larger network of (health service provider) organisations, the patient, care-givers et cetera, and consider the value creation from the network perspective.
• Students obtain practical skills in presenting, case work, reporting and discussing health care management problems in a scientifically sound manner, and using the English language
• Students learn how to cooperate and perform in diverse groups of students from various undergraduate programs and nationalities

column1: Due to the international and multidisciplinary orientation on health care management, the minor is of interest to students:

column2: • Health sciences - Gezondheidswetenschappen, Beleid & Management Gezondheidszorg (BMG)
• Medicine - Geneeskunde
• Business Administration - Bedrijfskunde
• Social Sciences - Sociale Wetenschappen (Sociologie, Bestuurskunde)
• Economics - Economie

column1: More than one third of the participants is not from Erasmus University, but from a variety of other universities among which are Amsterdam, Delft, Eindhoven, Leiden, Wageningen. The minor is also included in the 3rd year bachelor exchange programme for Health Sciences, and therefore also has incoming international exchange students.

The cases in the minor are partly from the Dutch health sector, which has been repeatedly ranked to be the best or among the best in the world. Moreover, the cases and articles present materials from a variety of countries such as Germany, India, UK, USA.

The minor continuously asks the students to work on cases in small and diverse groups and deliver a report every week. It expects students to be cooperative and motivated to work on a series of health care management cases for 9 weeks. A background in a related scientific discipline is helpful bot not required.
Maximum number of students that can participate: 50
Minimum number of students that can participate: 15

The minor has meetings twice or three times per week, on Monday, Wednesday and/or Friday. Some of the meeting are lectures, some are guest lectures; most rely on collaborative group work in which the students are in the lead and present, discuss, et cetera. Each week deals with a single topic. The students learn and study theory regarding this topic, apply the theory on a practical case, present and hand in their case work for grading. There will be visits to leading Dutch health care organisations.
In addition to the case work, there will be two written exam with essay questions. One after the first four weeks and one at the end of the course.

Composition of final grade:The results for the 2 written exam accounts for 60% of the final grade (exam grade), the remaining 40% is determined by the group case work and participation (group work grade). The exam grade and the group work grade need to be at least 5,0, and the final grade needs to be at least 5,5 to pass this course.
Weekly feedback via Blackboard on the cases.
Continuous feedback on participation and presentations (presentation skills are not graded).
Feedback on the written exam is upon appointment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82197,2018,Health Economic Development and Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. IEJ Bonfrer', 'M Rieger', 'N Wagner']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course examines the links between health, health spending and economic welfare at the individual and at the societal level. The course deals with two broad issues (i) the linkages between health and economic development, in particular, in the context of developing countries and (ii) an examination of the effectiveness of public health spending including issues such as absenteeism of health workers, corruption in the health sector and approaches that may be used to tackle corruption.

column2: • The relationship between health, income and development
• Health, health related behaviour and productivity
• Empirical measurement of health and the returns to health
• Impact assessment of health interventions
• Health and poverty traps
• Assessing allocation and effectiveness of public health spending
• Corruption and worker absenteeism in the health sector

column1: Increasing the effectiveness of public health spending – tackling corruption

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The two main aims of the course are to illustrate the link between health and economic development and to assess the rationale and effectiveness of public health expenditure, both, in the context of developing countries.

column2: • To introduce participants to the concept of health in development economics
• To provide an overview of possible transmission channels between health and development and development and health
• To discuss models explaining health related behaviour and health investment
• To provide an overview of the economic, political and social rationale for the public provision of health expenditure
• To equip participants with the necessary methodological insights required to understand and critically review econometric impact evaluations of health-related interventions

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/76484,2018,Health Economics (ESP25),Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. WK Redekop'],,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
As a student you’re likely to often say: “I am so stressed out!” What does that mean? Stress is our response to the demand for change.
When you are a student, you face many demands to change, for example your academic performance, your major choice, your

attitudes, and your behaviours. Are all of these demands bad? Is all stress bad? You’d probably be surprised, but the answer is no! Moderate stress levels are actually very good for you, and moderate stress is essential for learning. However, when stress takes over your life and you feel overwhelmed, then stress becomes a problem. In that case stress can have a negative impact on your health.

We have positive and destructive behavioural responses to stress. Destructive behaviours are smoking, drinking alcohol to get drunk, taking drugs, and overusing prescribed medications. All of these behaviours can bring short-term relief but at a high cost to your health. A healthier way to cope with stress is to plan for stressful events, like midterms, and to invest in time management skills. Other things to pay attention to are good and nutritious eating habits, regular sleep patterns, and exercise routines to ‘unwind’. These are all examples of types of behaviour that will help you to cope with stress in a healthy way. Coping with stress is only one example of behaviour as a key ingredient contributing to health. By using day-to-day examples in this course, we will explain how health psychology can be used to address behaviours that can affect our health. We will do this by (1) explaining how psychological, behavioural, and cultural factors contribute to physical health and illness, and (2) by exploring health promotion intervention design in a hands-on manner.

This course follows a project-based structure, meaning you will work on a project in small groups of 3-4 students. During this course you are expected to use the knowledge obtained in the lectures and tutorials to set up an intervention plan. You will present your intervention plan by way of a poster presentation to a group of healthcare professionals in the penultimate week of the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the reasons underlying the emergence of health psychology;
• Have a basic understanding of the public health consequences of hypertension, diabetes, and sexually transmitted diseases;
• Understand the determinants of health behaviour and identify effective methods of promoting behaviour change and healthier lifestyles;
• Understand the main health risks and positive health behaviours that are relevant to the population at large;
• Understand the role of health behaviours for determining health outcomes;
• Become familiar with behaviour change theories in public health;
• Identify trends in research about the evidence based clinical behaviour of health care professionals;
• Discuss the role of theories and techniques of behaviour change;
• Learn from the experiences of a GP working in the South of Rotterdam;
• Understand sociocultural differences of health and illness;
• Become familiar with a theoretical framework to understand cultural differences and similarities;
• Apply behaviour change theories to design a pilot intervention focused on hypertension/diabetes/sexual and reproductive health;
• Appreciate the challenges and opportunities associated with running an intervention in the field.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82212,2018,Health Service Operations Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. KE Tabeau', 'dr. S Sülz', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'prof.dr.ir. JMH Vissers']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in Excel is available.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) can be defined as the analysis, design, planning and control of all steps necessary to deliver services to clients in healthcare. We use methods and techniques that originate from manufacturing but have been adapted to service industries and health services.

The aim of the course is to make the students familiar with the basic concepts, methods and techniques of health service operations management and to enable them to apply these concepts to services in healthcare.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course focuses on the question; How can organizations develop and evaluate innovative services in health care. The course provides an introduction to innovation science.  Innovations science is interdisciplinary; it combines knowledge from the field of economics, sociology, change management and organizational sciences. Specific questions we will address in this course are: What is the value of specific innovations? What impact do technologies have on clinical practice? Why do certain innovations emerge while others do not? How can you evaluate an innovation (is it better compared to what, who, whom)?

In this course students are asked to participate in an innovation contest (comparable to the Dutch Health Care innovation Award). The examination of the course represents all elements of innovation and implementation processes. Students are asked to write a proposal, to present this proposal to both health care professionals, managers and board members and to review an innovation proposal

De voertaal in de colleges is Engels. In dit vak zijn er geen klassieke werkgroepen, want er is projectonderwijs. Je expliciet bij de vakcoordinator (weggelaar@eshpm.eur.nl) minimaal 3 weken van te voren melden dat je in een projectgroep wilt met alleen studenten die Nederlands spreken. Het rapport en de individuele opdracht mag in het Nederlands worden opgeleverd. De pitch moet in het Engels, maar in jouw werkgroep zitten EUHeM en HCM studenten, die de Engelse taal vloeiend beheersen (en slechts één of twee studenten hoeven te presenteren).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can design and steer an innovation process.
• Students can write a proposal for a care innovation prize which includes a description of the why, the what, the how and the implementation of the innovation;
• Students can apply management skills, e.g. collaboration in teams, project management, creative thinking, present a pitch, write a compact proposal and visualize ideas.
• Students can evaluate an innovation proposal with set of criteria based upon medical, economic, social, managerial an organization theories about innovations.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82181,2018,Health Technology Assessment,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. HM Blommestein', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. MJ Poleij', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Although patients demand access to all health care programmes available, the scarcity of resources necessitates that choices have to be made. Given that health is such an important matter and that choices usually have far reaching consequences for individuals, the choices require careful consideration, preferably based on transparent and unbiased data. Health Technology Assessment is a multidisciplinary research area closely related to health economics.  HTA research attempts to examine the short- and long-term consequences (e.g. health effects and costs) of new and existing health care programs.  This is done in a systematic and consistent way in order to provide evidence for the relative cost-effectiveness of health care programs. Policy makers in health care are increasingly using the results of these studies in making choices on priorities in health care.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course enables students to get both theoretical and practical knowledge on HTA-studies such as: design, costing, quality of life, modelling, analysis of uncertainty, ethical and equity aspects and other policy considerations. Students will be able to develop and perform all elements of standard HTA-studies, including economic evaluations. Students will also be trained in critically reviewing HTA-studies, in order to judge their validity and applicability. Students will get more knowledge on the usefulness of HTA-studies for policy making.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82229,2018,Healthcare Ethics,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. CM Dieteren', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80224,2018,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course we will focus on the procurement process and on value chain management in the healthcare sector. In many countries, healthcare represents one of the largest sectors of the economy; healthcare spend often amounts to 10% of a country’s GDP. This course builds on the key concepts as taught in the core course Purchasing & Supply Management (BM05SCM). This course expands into areas that are not only relevant in healthcare, but also in other sectors, such as services triads, performance-based contracting, best value procurement, European tendering, cooperative purchasing, and negotiation skills.

In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurers, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. catering, temporary labour and medical equipment).

A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course brings together students from the institute of Healthcare Policy and Management and Rotterdam School of Management to educate them on procurement in the healthcare sector. The course is a mix of lectures and workshops, some of which will be taught by experienced guest lecturers from organizations such as hospitals and insurance companies. The workshops are sessions with 10-20 students, in which there will be ample opportunity to discuss the concepts in-depth and/or to practice specific skills.

The lectures and workshops will be taken by both students from the Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management as well as Supply Chain Management. SCM students will start with an introduction lecture in May 2018, for the remainder of the schedule please refer to the GW4009MD and GW4009MV schedules.

Students will get to understand the role that purchasing plays within and between healthcare organisations and the different ways in which purchasing can contribute to the overall performance of a healthcare organisation and/or a healthcare system. Upon completing this course, students:

column2: • Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management in healthcare value chains;
• Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of supplier relationship management as well as the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of business and board alignment and how to achieve such alignment;
• Understand how European, national and local government policy affect purchasing in healthcare;

• Are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own (future) organisations and the value chain they operate in so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their value chain.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82220,2018,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVZ) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.
In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management in healthcare systems;
• Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and know the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of alignment between purchasing and medical professionals and how to achieve such alignment;
• Can describe the advantages of horizontal buyer-supplier collaboration and the different types of buyer-supplier relationships;
• Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and how municipalities in The Netherlands operate under such regulations as they contract procviders of social care.

• Are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own organisations so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their organisation.
