column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.

Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).

Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.
Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel.</mystyle></body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/77501,2018,Hemato-oncologie,Nederlands,Erasmus MC Academie,,[],,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81832,2018,Het (moderne en postmoderne) subject: tussen autonomie en determinisme,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw (tot tegenwoordig) trekken vele filosofen en wetenschappers de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Ageren we altijd rationeel of zijn wij vrij in onze handelingen en beslissingen? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?

In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw zoals Freud, Nietzsche, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Fanon, en Foucault. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden. Tot besluit bediscussiëren wij (met het oog op huidige debatten in neurowetenschap en AI) of het moderne subject zomaar vervangen kan worden of ook in de toekomst nog een belangrijke rol kan en moet spelen.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten Filosofie.

Aan het einde van de cursus heeft de student/e inzicht in de verschillende concepten van het subject via de wordingsgeschiedenis daarvan en de kritische uiteenzettingen daarmee in de moderne tijd. Ze/hij is in staat om de argumenten in de behandelde teksten te identificeren en samen te vatten. Zij/hij geeft een onderbouwde redenering over de deugdelijkheid van de genoemde kritiekpunten (die gericht zijn tegen het concept van een autonoom een rationeel subject).</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81143,2018,Heuristic Skills and Sources,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. GA Noordzij', 'dr. JW Schaap', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'EA Stevens, MA']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80182,2018,High Performance Leadership,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. TIN Davidson', 'HW Lam, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The only thing that all organisations have in common is that they are made up of people. And, indeed, there is a growing realisation that organisational success and an organisation’s ability to gain a competitive advantage is critically contingent on their effective management of these people. Leaders are the key players in these processes. They are in the position to motivate employees to excellent performance and mobilise employees for the organisation’s mission and vision. At the same time, however, they may also be a primary source of conflict and de-motivation. Understanding what makes for high performance leadership as well as where leadership can go wrong, therefore, is of critical importance to successful organisational functioning. This course explores theory, research, and practice of leadership effectiveness to build a deeper understanding of leadership processes, and the dos and don’ts of leadership.

The course offers an in-depth treatment of key issues in the psychology of leadership. It not only looks at the practical implications of theories in the area, but also highlights state-of-the-art research to develop analytical thinking about effective leadership.

The course consists of a series of interactive lectures where theory and research in leadership are explored. Complementing this focus on theory and research, participants will engage with practical issues in leadership in hands-on assignments in small teams. Students will learn how to apply theoretical insights into consulting practice within organizational contexts of leadership. Students will present their findings to an audience of fellow students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Learning goals: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: <li>

understand and apply the state-of-the-art theories in leadership (i.e., transformational vs. transactional leadership; servant leadership; implicit leadership theories; identity based leadership; leadership development)
<li>
combine different theoretical approaches and determine the strength and weaknesses of the approaches
<li>
communicate theoretically sound and practical recommendations in a persuasive manner
<li>
feel comfortable when analyzing leadership strength and failures
<li>
give practical recommendations for “better” leadership

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83686,2018,High-Performance Brain Simulation,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80426,2018,Highlights of Sociology,Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['dr. AS Leerkes', 'dr. R Kemmers']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Although one can trace the origins of sociology way back in history the emergence of sociology as an academic discipline is strongly related to what is called 'modernity'. Modernity is a sociological catchword for a number of significant social transformations that were particularly notable in the 19th and early 20th century. Expressed in a dynamic way 'modernization' refers to the rise of capitalist industrial society that entails an emerging money economy, new ways of making a living, a process of fast urbanization, making sense of the world in terms of new ideologies and meanings, the formation of new types of households and the rise of state bureaucracies. The combination of these developments had a profound impact on the everyday life of ordinary people. The founders of modern academic sociology - which, by the way, is itself part of the process of modernisation it tried to understand and explain - attempted to make sense of what they saw, basically by comparing the emerging 'modern' with 'traditional' society. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, the relation between work and leisure, what it means to live in an urbanized world, the relation of individuals with society.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.

In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms; Identity performance; Political distrust; Gender segregation in the labour market; Deviance and social problems; Religion and Atheism; Sociology of Globalization.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82986,2018,Hippocampal field recording,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,"['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81176,2018,Historical Culture in a Globalising World,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'prof.dr. MCR Grever']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The past is not simply gone. It permeates people's lives through memory and imagination, and offers them an orientation in time. Telling stories about what happened in the past plays a key role in the construction of personal and collective identities (nation-states and other political entities). Narratives of past glory and empire are crucial to global communities and international political relations. Yet the instrumental ways of dealing with time and the growing resistance to differentiate the past from the here-and-now might subvert the orientation in time and weaken the awareness of reality.

A central concept to understand these and similar processes is historical culture. The concept refers to historical narratives and performances, to the infrastructure of the historical field which makes it possible for people to deal with past, and to different conceptions of history. It enables the study of changing ""past-relationships"" in the world in an integrated way.

This course provides theoretical reflection on historical culture and discusses methods, such as the use of various time-concepts, the making of narrative plotlines, and the construction of periodizations. We will study several cases, such as mapping space and time in world exhibitions, tracing identity performances of the European Union, comparing the politics of descent in political speeches, and analysing the narrative scripts of historical reconciliation committees.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can explain the meanings of historical culture in the context of a globalising world, based on relevant conceptions of time and narrative theories, both orally and in writing.

• Students can interpret articulations of transforming social and political attitudes towards the past in various sources and can present their interpretations with philosophical and historical arguments.
• Students are able to recognize different elements of historical narration, including composition, narrative plot and methods.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81157,2018,Historical Representation and Imagination,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. SM Hogervorst', 'L Zurné, MA', 'S.M. Hogervorst']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Images of the past evoke feelings of recognition, resistance or nostalgia. They can have a major mobilizing force. For instance, images of a greedy French Queen in 1785 encouraged the French people to rebel against the monarchy; in 1919, German posters about the Treaty of Versailles discredited the social-democratic government; in the late 1960s, photo's about the Vietnam war in the newspapers triggered mass protests against the American government.

This course focuses on historical representations and images since ca. 1750, its contents, narrative and pictural structure, functions and political and social impact. We will discuss some interesting case-studies: icons of the nation-states in Europe; rituals of the British and Dutch monarchy; the use of historical wall charts in Dutch schools; historical re-enactments; heritage of 'dark tourism'; the imagination of World War II in musicals and new media. Students will discuss and present papers on these topics, based on theoretical concepts that elaborate the process of historical representation and imagination: visual culture, collective memory, identity, historical consciousness, re-mediation, heritage, lieu de mémoire and invention of tradition.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students acquire knowledge about various historical representations and imaginations in past and present, such as monuments, exhibitions, commemorations, historical re-enactments, pictures, films,TV-series, and video games. They can contextualize and critically assess these images of the past in view of its functions for specific communities. They are capable to produce written papers and oral presentations in proper (Dutch or English) language on relevant topics of this course, based on the discussed theories about visual culture and collective memory.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81163,2018,Historical databases: Demography and Social Mobillity,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. CA Mandemakers'],,"Inhoud

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: The rise of the modern family (marriage at an older age and the birth of fewer children) started in the 1930’s; whether or not migrants were successful depends on the conditions they were in when they left; the chances of living longer depends on the living conditions in the first two years after birth.

These perceptions can only be tested by using databases that contain data of large numbers of persons covering complete life histories or a complete era. Some databases, in the Netherlands CLIO _Infra, contain composite data such as average income and number of inhabitants of complete countries. Some databases contain data about complete life courses, such as the age at death, income or number of children (Historical Sample of the Netherlands (HSN) or the census datasets from the Minesota Population Center). During the seminar the focus will be on the practice of using these databases. The subjects to be studied will give a good impression of the richness of these datasets and contain issues like social mobility, educational development, migration and mortality. Students will not be asked to enter data themselves; the databases will be put at their disposal by the teacher or will be downloaded.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

By now the historical community disposes of an increasing number of large-scale databases which are accessible to all scientists. Students learn how to use these historical databases by studying the structure, content and way of presentation of these databases and by acquiring methods how to study the data.

Students acquire knowledge of and are taught how to work with large historic datasets. This is done by studying the structure, content and way of presentation of these datasets, by downloading the data and by learning methods how to use these data. In addition to this students learn how to formulate scientific research questions, how to make a relatively simple analysis and how to sensibly communicate on this, both orally and in a written form.
In order to be able to follow this course, prior knowledge in statistics at the level or comparable with the level of the course Quantitative Historical Sources (Bachelor 2) is required“

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. In this workshop we will critically assess the impact and the implementation on a local, national and supranational level of this policy instrument. Academic texts will be compared with policy and consultancy texts, and the concept will be discussed in a historical, social and economic context. Finally, the workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative industries and aims to analyse different sectors of the industry, including fashion, art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82171,2018,History and Theory of International Economic Relations,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. HAM Klemann'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Until the 19th century trade was additional. Production focused on local consumption. The Industrial Revolution resulted in the use of mineral raw materials that could not locally be produced. Consequently, trade became more intense. At the end of the 19th century, the then for substantial parts colonialized countries of the Southern hemisphere supplied the West with raw materials. After World War II trade became more and more trade in diversified industrial products among the Western countries, but from the 1970s on, outsourcing and a change in policy in the South, resulted in a complete change not just of trade, but even of industrial production. The splitting up of the chains of production over a number of localities, often organized by multinational companies, not just caused an enormous increase of trade, but also in a huge growth of industrial production in previously backwards, and therefore low-wage areas. Consequently, trade grew again faster than production. The theories of international economic relations, from the ideas of Ricardo, Heckscher and Ohlin, Stolper and Samuelson, till the concepts of Krugman, the ideas on monetary policy, on international finance and on political interference in international economic relations will be discussed to see whether these can explain developments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

·        Students can explain that in the 19th and 20th century international trade grew much faster than the global economy, that trade and economic growth are related and how the period of the World Wars and the Great Depression undermined this development, and so international trade.
·        As a consequence, they can recognize the results of political interference in international economic developments. From the 1970s, however, economic globalization recovered.

Students can interpret the general development in international trade in the last two centuries, using some basic theoretical concepts on economic trade, open-economy macro-economics, monetary relations, stable and floating currency rates, FDIs.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81347,2018,History behind writing,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['Drs. T.A. Pronk', 'drs. TA Pronk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Any historian digging in the past sooner or later comes across manuscripts. This course examines a number of different genres (or kind of manuscripts) from the Middle Ages onwards: such as diaries, chronicles or government-records. Doing so, this course foremost deals with the history ‘behind’ such primary sources. It turns out that the rise of various uses of handwriting reflect a number of historical developments. Against what historical background did these arise? It becomes clear why European society became increasingly lettered, and writing an indispensable part of every-day life. The course will start with 18/19th<sup>th</sup> century diaries and gradually proceed to older kind of handwritten texts, such as medieval city-charters and bibles.     </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The student comes to understand the role handwriting has played in the formation of European society since the Middle Ages. The students learns the significance of different genres of manuscript : diaries, travel-journals, administrative records, chronicles, charters, letters and books. The student understands the interrelationship between these genres and a number of major historical processes (such as urbanization, reformation, state-formation or the rise of the public sphere). This enables the student to explain the different functions of manuscript in history. Finally, the student will be able to read different handwritings-styles, understands the peculiarities of pre-modern texts (letters, abbrevations, etc.) and knows the rules for transcription of old texts.

This course deals with constructs of culture and of cultural difference in early modern and modern history within the context of European expansion and colonial order as well of in the context of diaspora and migration. Principal concepts such as “culture” and “identity” will be critically reviewed, tracing its uses in the various contexts. The following twin notions will be dealt with: culture-identity, difference-equality, majority-minority, native-migrant, insiders-outsiders, orientalism-occidentalism.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October 2018.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 8.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81142,2018,History of Early Modern Societies,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. GA Noordzij', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'Drs. T.A. Pronk', 'drs. TA Pronk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have been to easily projecting their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students are introduced to the history of early modern societies between 1300 and 1750. They will acquire new insights into the structural changes that took place in Europe and in the wider world during this period. Students are able to analyse historical argumentative texts and use this skill of the so-called structure analysis in producing papers and an oral presentation.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Lectures/seminars provide a general overview of the history of economics, with more detailed analysis of particular issues and problems, the precise coverage sometimes being varied to reflect the interests of those taking the course each year. Students are expected to read recommended materials beforehand, so that the lectures can focus on a discussion of the readings. The first four lectures provide an outline of the history of economics up to the second world war, with subsequent lectures covering a range of more modern topics.
1-2. Adam Smith, the market and trade

Readings are selected to introduce students to a range of approaches to the subject. For example, Adam Smith is used to show how reading an economist through the lens of modern economics may be to impose ideas foreign to his or her thought; the lecture on Keynes introduces the idea of approaching the history of economics through an economist’s biography. Subsequent lectures give examples of work that debunks myths and which shows how changing philosophical presuppositions can change the way economic arguments are constructed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1) Explain how economic ideas may be influenced by the context in which they arose and may reflect philosophical values and attitudes different from our own.
2) Provide and comment on examples of different approaches to writing the history of economics.

3) Identify and analyse some of the major themes that historians of economics have identified, such as the “marginal” revolution, the transition from interwar pluralism to postwar neoclassical economics, the Keynesian revolution, or the recent turn to applied economics.
4) Explain, using one or more examples, how the historian’s perspective on episodes in the history of economics may differ from that of a modern economist.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course provides an introduction to the history of western societies since 1750. Structural changes in politics, culture and the economy are discussed. In addition, students are trained to close-read and interpret primary sources from this period and to report their findings in oral and written presentations.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81051,2018,History of Western Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['B Boross, MA', 'D Ribeiro Povoa', 'drs. AG van Ham', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.  Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81075,2018,History of the Art Market,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EG Mannheimer', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. Attention will be given - among other topics - to the innovations that were introduced to expand the market for works of art since early modern times. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 55.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course seeks to familiarize the students with the history and functioning of early modern and modern art markets. They will be exposed to the recent findings concerning the socio-economic, but also the cultural and sociological framework in which works of art were and are produced, traded and consumed. An interdisciplinary approach will be pursued in order to gain insight into these phenomena.</body>

History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation-state, heritage and public history.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus beoogt studenten dieper kennis te laten maken met de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit. Studenten maken kennis met verschillende hedendaagse toonaangevende discussies binnen deze vier thema’s, en leren reflecteren op diverse prominente onderzoeksproblemen.

Aan de hand van deze verdieping in de centrale thema’s van de sociologie, wordt aandacht besteed aan de vertaalslag van sociologische theorie naar empirie. De student leert hoe puzzels binnen de thema’s modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit kunnen worden onderzocht met behulp van empirisch onderzoek. Naast het behandelen van voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen deze vier thema’s, leren studenten hoe ze zelf theoretische begrippen kunnen aanwenden voor de formulering van empirisch toetsbare vragen of verwachtingen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student maakt zich prominente sociologische theorieën rondom de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie eigen: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.
• De student is in staat om centrale begrippen binnen de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie te beschrijven en toe te passen op hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken.
• De student maakt kennis met voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen de vier hoofdthema’s en leert onderzoeksartikelen kritisch te bestuderen.
• De student beschikt over het vermogen om zelf sociologische theorieën te gebruiken om empirische verschijnselen te duiden.
• De student is in staat om empirisch toetsbare vragen en verwachtingen te formuleren op basis van sociologische theorieën over modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.
• Bachelor-3 studenten maken een additionele schrijfopdracht (ter grootte van 1,5 ECTS).

column3: De psychologie is een breed vak met verschillende subdisciplines, zoals sociale psychologie, persoonlijkheidspsychologie en ontwikkelingspsychologie. Tijdens deze minor maken studenten kennis met een aantal psychologische fenomenen uit het leven van alledag. Voorbeelden van vragen die aan bod komen zijn: hoe betrouwbaar is ons geheugen? Heeft het zin om hard na te denken, of kun je beter op je intuïtie vertrouwen? Word je slimmer door veel klassieke muziek te luisteren? Kunnen sommige mensen echt de toekomst voorspellen?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organized in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms “work” (as studied in physiology) without having a fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).

In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English);
• learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints;
• be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation;
• be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax;
• learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively;
• learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus gaat het over human enhancement, ook wel ‘mensverbetering’ genoemd. Nieuwe (bio-)technologische mogelijkheden die  in eerste instantie bedoeld zijn om ziekten te genezen, kunnen ook worden ingezet om de menselijk vorm, het functioneren of bepaalde capaciteiten te verbeteren voorbij dat wat we ‘normaal’ of ‘gezond’ noemen. Deels zijn dit soort toepassingen nog hypothetisch en futuristisch, deels al realiteit.
Het debat over de wenselijkheid van deze ontwikkelingen is fel en vaak sterk gepolariseerd. In deze cursus worden verschillende posities in dit debat besproken en met elkaar geconfronteerd.

Na een algemeen overzicht en positionering van het debat in wetenschappelijke, historische en filosofische context, wordt specifiek ingegaan op enkele cruciale begrippen en argumenten in het debat: natuurlijkheid, menselijke natuur, het leven als ‘gift’, de spanning tussen controle en acceptatie, en het principe van ‘procreative beneficence’.
Tijdens het onderwijs zal behalve aandacht voor de inhoudelijke argumenten ook aandacht zijn voor de verschillen in stijl en benadering tussen de diverse auteurs.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Na afloop van deze cursus kan de student in grote lijnen weergeven wat de filosofische posities in het debat over human enhancement zijn, en welke filosofische en ethische vragen in dit debat van belang zijn.
• De student kan uitleggen welke verbanden er zijn tussen geneeskunde en enhancement
• De student kan uitleggen hoe de begrippen natuurlijkheid, menselijke natuur en ‘giftedness’  worden geïnterpreteerd en gebuikt door verschillende auteurs binnen het human enhancement-debat
• De student kan uitleggen wat het principle of procreative beneficence is, en welke kritiek daarop mogelijk is.
• De student kan een eigen beargumenteerde visie geven op (aspecten van) human enhancement.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80391,2018,Human Physiology,Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['dr. A Mora Cortes', 'dr. M Martinez Claros']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

It is vital for humans that organ systems do their jobs - but even more important is that these systems communicate (share information via molecules) with each other. Without this interdependency, the organism as a whole will not survive. Physiology is a field that describes these vital functions of living organisms, organs, cells, and molecules.

Cells and organs occupy a highly protected internal aqueous environment surrounded by extracellular fluid. The composition of this extracellular fluid needs to be kept under strict control. The control of this extracellular fluid and other vital parameters is called homeostasis. Homeostasis functions at a level of a single cell (e.g. intracellular volume and energy levels) or at the level of the entire organism (e.g. arterial pressure and core body temperature). This course focuses on homeostasis at the organism level.

Negative (sometimes also positive) feedback mechanisms are responsible for homeostasis. When a parameter is very vital for the entire organism, the body has multiple overlapping (redundant) systems in place to regulate it. These mechanisms tend to always push the parameter back towards a steady state.

Based on the above, it’s easy to come to a conclusion that medicine is the study of physiology out of homeostasis, which can lead to a disease (i.e., pathology). However, during this course we will focus on discussing the “normal” functioning of the human body.

In this course, the spotlight will be on the structure and functioning of the human body. The structure and function of various tissues and organs will be discussed in many details, looking at histological samples. This will contribute to a better understanding how organs function within systems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:

column2: • Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
• Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
• Know the normal vital physiological parameters.
• Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
• Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86518,2018,Human Resource Management,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,[],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This module focuses on the strategic level of HRM: how can we use HRM practices to achieve long term viability for (public) organizations. Notwithstanding this strategic orientation, the importance of ‘tactical’ HRM (e.g. which HRM practices ‘work’ and why) will be also dealt with. The first part of the module will discuss the theoretical background of strategic HR: what is it and why is it important? In

the second part several more concrete themes (e.g. training, work design, motivation, leadership) will addressed using recent academic literature. Although the focus will be on ‘general mechanisms’, students will be asked in this part to reflect on the usability of these mechanisms in the context of a developing country. This reflection will be supported by a discussion of several academic articles about HRM related themes in developing countries.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This course introduces students to key theories, concepts and empirical findings about HRM in the public sector. The course aims to provide students with an understanding about what HRM is, and how it can be applied in order to motivate employees. After the course students should be able to apply general HRM theory and insights to the context of developing countries.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80622,2018,Human Resource Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. RL Hewett']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In many industries, the personnel – or the Human Resources – of an organization are one of the most vital factors shaping an organization’s success or failure. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, or the exit of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains or losses and have potential legal implications for the organization but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied. Effectively managing a company’s Human Resources thus requires an appreciation of how people-decisions are shaped by and shape individuals’ motivation, well-being, productivity, and identification with the organization they work for.

This course offers you an evidence-based and multidisciplinary perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource and People Management. We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of Human Resource Management including the key strategic role of successful HR management, the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from the human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialization process. Building on this, a number of sessions deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and compensating their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Considering the final stage in the employee lifecycle, we will then consider how to manage employee’s voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations. We finish the course by considering the critical role of people analytics in modern HR management, and reflecting on the latest challenges in HRM. Throughout this course, we will highlight interesting cases that illustrate how these techniques and practices work out in organizations. By the end of the class, you will therefore have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with regard to the most important HR practices in light of the empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.

Given that Human Resource Management is a central organizational function that supports many other functions (e.g., human resources are needed to realize strategic plans) this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. Of particular importance are the courses of Organizational Behaviour which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and the course on Organizational Theory & Dynamics as the effectiveness of Human Resource practices is often contingent on how well it is aligned with the broader organizational structure.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After following this course, students will be able to

column2: <li>
Describe and explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
<li>
Recognize and link this knowledge to practical people management problems and challenges.
<li>
Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical considerations to critically analyse and suggest solutions for people management problems and cases.
<li>
Reflect on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of HR and people managers.
<li>
Employ basic people management techniques and skills in your own workplace interactions.

column1: At the end of this course you should have acquired or improved your skills in the following areas:

column2: • Analytical thinking;
• Problem identification and problem solving;
• Working in groups and group dynamics.
